New Year’s Day.
I look forth at midnight to grimmest fog, fog that is as a garment to the bitter wind.
A moon in the heavens, bells & cannon on the Air. Then a human cheer across the waters 1904 is with us – for our fashioning
more and more I feel this, we are weavers of the stuff of time
Henry

note.p: One of Bradley’s many nicknames for Cooper.

p.hi: says there was lack of spirituality in us last year. I remind him the Holy Ghost has his seasons, winter & spring & summer. We have been with God, creating.
We need clemency & breadth – acknowledgement of no boundary.
Strange! - Henry, not having need this, saw far-open horizons.
He smelt pine & carnation; that is what is comfortable in the descent from the opened heavens.
It is terrible to begin with raw time again, just when one was at work on a nice bit of mellow stuff.
I feel that my business this year will
Notebook 18, Page Image 10; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 4v; Hind AlJarboa
be loving - I have scarcely touched the power of loving within me. I mean that plastic loving that is influence. Little Amy
Little Amy is Edith Cooper’s sister.

writes that her motto for this year is – “let us beware lest we act as he did in the fable, who stood watch in the lighthouse, & gave to the poor in the cabins about him the oil of the night’s lanterns that served to illumine the sea. Every soul in its sphere has charge of a lighthouse for which there is more or less need”
Failures & sins of 1903
No influence from art, none from literature, except the re-reading of [Rev?] & the power from Aristophanes Glimpses from Nature we had, Heaven bless her!
I will try to read a little this year – one or two big-lettered books.
But there will be little leisure-accomplishing, reaping, singing; but only as we bind the grain – this is revealed our destiny.
There is an Imagination to feed dearer than my own, & a soul to cherish in her cell.
I want to write of Diana of Poictiers
Diana de Poictiers was a French noblewoman and a prominent courtier at the courts of King Francis I and his son, King Henry II of France.
, & of the French Renaissance.
I want my Beloved to write [???] tower all by herself.
[Notebook 18, Page Image 11; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 5r; Hind AlJarboa]
We are in our fresh, spring -like room again – & an Old Persian rug lies on the hearth - It is quite a creature to lie on the hearth, is a Persian Rug.
I have set our affairs in order, while the Eastern frost has been dissolving into southern fog. My Love has brought me tender Anemones & three lily-buds as green & crisp as new year itself.
January 5
th
My Chow
Whym Chow was a dog Bradley and Cooper had acquired. His death led to their conversion to Roman Catholicism.
is ill with gastritis – I suffer with him. Francis
Francis Thompson was an English poet and ascetic.
is here, so we are with the past.
Ernest
Ernest Radford was an English poet, critic and socialist.
writes to ask as if we will suffer ourselves to be “re-maindered” they are removing to premises.
I write to him

“It makes one’s skin very hot to think of being “remaindered”. It is one of those uncomfortable processes, like what goes on in the slave. But we in our free spirits are apart from both these processes. So what matter!
So “remainder” freely.
“Tommy”
Thomas Sturge Moore was an English poet, author and artist.
who left us without good-bye & sent us no cake – writes to excuse himself. He has been
[Notebook 18, Page Image 12; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 5v; Hind AlJarboa & Andy Ward
lost in the ceremonial of marriage, & then his mother’s death came on him - I reply
-Of course we rolled you over the abyss as a lost friend on New Year’s Eve. And therefore you have to toil, with Marie to help up too! I shouldn’t wonder, if she helped you up: we shall see…
We in England have been spending the time like masters. Doubtless you will see the artists’ new pictures, & Ricketts’s great deposition....

div.p: January 6th
Epiphany – the [graciens?] Star Feast. The intellectual recognition of Christ Wise & with Wisdom wise these that recognize him & knew it is worth while travelling far to worship him.
Little Francis John before his bubbly bowl of milk. “Mother, is this bubble a kiss from Auntie Ethel or from God.”
The Mother, I fear, did not answer “Straight from God.”

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 13; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 6r; Andy Ward

div.p: It is on this blessed feast of the Epiphany a new play is given to Henry - a play of Redemption – Henry must write

But I am with the Savage, blood – dripping old grandfather Herod,
A king of Judea appointed by the Roman Empire who ruled during the time of Jesus Christ’s birth. He appears in the Biblical birth narrative of Jesus as the person who wanted to have the baby Jesus killed. with his lust for love. He must have love – Mariamne’s
A princess and the second wife of Herod. Known for her great beauty. Herod later had her killed out of jealousy even though he loved her deeply. love – his children’s love. He has a burning lust for love – the love of his wife, his offspring – his people. He has not the [????] of his ambition - none. He would like even to be loved of God, & in profanity he dedicates the temple. He murders love wherever it might spring up.

He is a man who seeks tears as other men seek gold. He would leave lamentation [????], & regret as a heritage. He would transfer emotion - the great office of art – but he is not an artist. He works in a medium of which he has not the secret.
Mariamne is to him beauty and desire – her refusal to love him transcends in wonder – and that his children should not love him – that the worms alone should love him and cleave to him!
He is not despicable. He has sought for the best thing life can give. He seeks to attract & to possess, not as a God.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 14; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 6v; Andy Ward

div.p: I saw in the night a scene with his children. The body of Mariamne in a sarcophagus in a dim corner of the room. His [????] still children have [????] in.
- they approach, but cannot look in. Do not let us talk of it –
No: we shall remember better if we do not speak.

It is something they must learn in silence. But is it our Mother? – Aristobulus
Prince of Judea; son of Herod and Marianme. – I do not care. I shall be a great soldier. – let us play new at taking – [????].
(they sit down & play at taking a city)
Herod enters: he stands for a long time by the coffin.
to-day I hate thee. to-day I will arouse thy sulleness. that hate in the metres of a woman’s [????] that frenzies – No:
No, Mariamne. deal more patiently, as I shall weary of this solemn face – and beauty that is absent as the sky. Well, children at your play –
(they rise & leave the toys on the ground. Well, children, children! Come back! …
Why were you playing in this room - Who gave you leave – What [????] you -
(the children stand trembling violently before him)

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 15; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 7r; Andy Ward

div.p: Herod convulsively clutches them, & holds them down one on each side.

You shall always love her. Listen, you know she is a goddess now your mother – She - But we must be afraid of her, she is not [????] You on the [earth?], as [????] [????] – she cannot understand. But you – my children.
I love you in your play – I would not break it – this city you besiege it.
One of the boys nods: with trembling hands Herod sets up some of the pieces I will play with you. No – do not watch me. I will play with you. You must talk & teach me how to play.
(He sobs as the children remain stubborn)
What would you like to do? You are dull. Should you like me to tell you a story?
(They shake their heads]
Not a story – not of – he gives lists of the great moments of his life.
You will become great as I am great. I can teach you that. Will you not listen? – When I was in Rome-

p.hi: Aristobulus

div.p: Father, we wll go to Rome. Lead us away to Rome.
(the spring away frightened of themselves.]
Herod –
To Rome – he remains [staring?], at the thought.

div.p: the younger one turns back, & kisses his hand.
- My we go father, may we go – We shall come back.

Friday, January 8th – the Palace
Charles Ricketts and Charles Shannon move away from Richmond to 'the Palace' in Lansdowne House, Holland Park.

Painter
One of the women’s nicknames for Charles Shannon. is sitting over the fire – a little bilious. We close into deep talk, & cannot go on-to the Manor - From 3 to 5:35 we converse.

Painter, believing it is the last night of the old year, starts for the theatre on January 30th. Deep horror freezes his vitals as he recollects he has not <re-> lit the stores; & that he will return to a palace of dead ashes!!!
He prophecies a year of transition – inevitable transition
“Herod - I have brought you his history. [????] whether Cleopatra may come in – not of course Shakespeare’s Cleopatra – the [????] disastrous little wretch of reality.”

John Gray
Refers to a friend who was a poet turned Catholic priest. There was a lengthy exchange of letters between these friends. Michael Field also had a friendship with a John Gray who was the curator of the Scottish National Portrait Gallery. has sent another little blue book. He has called at the Palace. Ricketts was out & Shannon
English painter and lifelong partner of Charles Ricketts. “denied himself.”

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page 17; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 8r; Andy Ward & Samah Damanhoori.

div.p: Designs of the gigantic Sabbatai ring are shown. There will be many windows.
“Will there be any doors” - , & this childish talk between consideration of Cleopatra – reaches into art & drawer.
The Painter is formed architect & sculptor. [????] – his grand-plan of the ring.
“I am right – he never forgives, a plant that has been cut, may shoot out in other directions –not where its life is destroyed.”
He has done a most exquisite thing – laid the softest coloured shells in a bowl of dried rose-leaves.
1st Sunday after Epiphany.
Anyone can see that the rose in the sky is of the spring- the gale brings Herod, & the first stage direction to Henry- he forms in the round; he is no longer a fresco.
I write

Shells musical as [Eolus?] had stirred, shells mouled finely as the waters mould, in bloom of ivory breathing through her gold, or white of foamy curd I gave; found preferred to a great bowl of roses leaves where they lie. In open burial crystal to the sky.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 18; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 8v; Samah Damanhoori

div.p: A shell! - It is a lovely testament, a bequeathed relic, & treasure wove breath upon breath; It holds each element as in an urn; shall it not speak of love?

Heralds there are of Love, the dusky flock of sparrows, or the doves in snowy brood that steer her chariot through the tempest’s shock, or bees, a honey-heaving multitude: Heralds there are & tokens of our state, and there are symbols set among the stars of man, his destiny, his chainèd Fate, the way that opens & the way that bars: and in between passing from hand to hand, there is the jewel and the signet-rose, censor, or brand of warm spring smell; I, in my mysteries pluck none of those; but trust for all my spirit would command the silence & the perfume of a shell.

Jan 12

div.p: I approach my birthday (Tues) with toothache that for an hour or so every evening is like Othello’s sword of ice-brook temper! The pain comes out a little distance into the air & is a power that resists touch! The day before I write the first scene (end) of Herod. We over-work it on my birthday morning. Amy comes from the old manor charmed with the new matting, & the white rooms in their bounty of flowers. [Re?] lilies, many-budded roses, a poutines garland for the white bowl of anemones & their curls of leafage. Young [????]-, all these are from my Love. Amy brings bubbles of milky <vale.> lilies, & tulips in [????] scarlet. And the light from the river falls on the delicate creatures reg receptively.
My gift from Michael is Placidia - the satinwood chest that enwombs Works & Days. Her noble extra [????] Macchiavelli comes not. Amy sweetly & [unwillingly?] gives a cheque toward an old Eastern rug.

div.p: < Wednes >
Thursday. Jan. 14th

Michael is in Sloane St. at 4 – the bee-bit! I am conscious with pain – strained in looks – I see he hesitates to stay. But I re-assure him that the actual pain is at night. I am much vexed he has hurried to return the vol. of Graetz
Heinrich Graetz (1817-1891) was a German Jewish Historian. He was amongst the first historian to write a comprehensive history of the Jewish people from a Jewish perspective. just on the day Michael had not offered for a visit – He explains Thursday & Friday are engaged – so he trotted over the first possible day & never thought of absence as possible.

He is sombre, unreflexing as mist & makes a “dead-set against Herod”,
Herod refers to a trilogy of plays Katherine and Edith were writing simultaneously around this time. whom he conceives as simply a figure of Eastern yearning – the desire that has no ideality. When Caesar dreams ambitiously it is to found a world – an order, a new order. There is ideality, which is creativeness in him – in Alexander. But the ambition of the East is a hunger. It is like the yearning of the north for the south – it wants the limitless stupidly. Only [????] the Mediterranean is ambition.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 21; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793; fol. 10r, Wendy Walter

div.p:
a mode of creation. Fay
Fay is a nickname for Charles Ricketts. can-be interested in nothing that has not been Mediterranianised. He is not even caught by the Arab strain in Herod. The Arabs are only thin Jews – they merely lack the [????] of soil of Judea The Jews have only given <the world> a moral code admirable for barbarians and the lower classes – the Arabs have added to manners on their <a> more superficial side. They have a calm, a grandeur – something nobly caressing in their ways. The Jews are effective, & therefore an Artist must admire them; but they have been a curse on civilisation blighting it two fold – by the family & by their moral code. In Greece men were reared to be citizens – the family was but the means. Life meant the spiritual conflict of the males. Wherever Jewish influence has been preponderant – civilized life declines – as when the Puritans ruined the civilization of England till a Latin influence ( [????] of France) partially restored it. Morality is a matter of pure convenience – what is best to do to get the best results (as gardening

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 22; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793; fol. 10v, Wendy Walter

div.p: is the art of getting the best flowers) – this the Greek took for granted; but the Jew came & made morality absolute – a code not an Art & this is the Semitic curse.

Christ was not by mind a Jew. His delicate skepticism was utterly different from anything found among the Jews – his ways of behaviour were opposed to Jewish morality. The influence of Christianity has been [Pauline?] & therefore Jewish It is only as it were aside & mostly in free-thinking times that the direct influence of Jesus can be traced.

Yet when all is said against the Jews Fay finds them almost the only people to talk to in England -They have two virtues – they are always foreigners & they have a tradition behind them. One always knows what to deal with – there are order & cleanness in them…not that incalculable confused element found in semi-barbarous people like the English, who have no permanent tradition as a nation – only in certain

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 23; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793; fol. 11r, Wendy Walter

div.p: families & castes.

Fay does not find wishes to rub in the unessentialness of the Jews -he thinks it is necessary for us, considering Michael’s old-fashioned education in the Psalms- “O God give me a good dinner” – “O God, give me health.” [????]

He does not find the [Knudos?] in Herod – He is full of the Tragedy of the Bloody Mary
Queen Mary I of England, 1516-1558. Because of the many executions of Protestants during her reign, she was nicknamed Bloody Mary. (he has dropped Queen Elizabeth). She should be treated as the Virgin Mary in history – she who felt that the deliverance of England was from her & of her child. Only by her means could God’s Kingdom be established & a light shine on her people. She dreams the child – she takes as husband the perfection <paragon> of Catholic tradition – The King of Spain that the child may be born – then the seven swords enter her heart. As she decreases the gay princess Elizabeth, the symbol of all the irreligion Mary would stifle, increase & [????] gleams over the [????] that measure its profundity. As women, Fay thinks we should be able to treat the frustrate religion & maternity of the woman.

div.p: January 19th.
Tuesday evening.
The long month so [far?] with business & pettiness - mere wash of refuse to the billows of Herod - rolls along.

We are firm in Herod now - the dead eyes are kindling – Cypros
Herod’s Arabian mother. Salome
A character in the Herod play., Mariamne
The love interest of Herod in the Herod plays. – Herod.

I have seen Herod with his arm round Aristobulus
Aristobulus is the beautiful young son of Mariamne in the Herod plays., caressing him.

Lady Anne Blunt’s
Lady Ann Blunt is the granddaughter of Lord Byron and a Baroness, traveled extensively in the Arabian Peninsula. She and her husband raised Arabian horses. He was a poet. She wrote two books: Bedouin Tribes of the Euphrates and A Pilgrimage to Nejd. “Poets of the [????]” comes to us a sheaf from Arabian store-houses.

We feel the white teeth of the camomile
“we feel the white teeth of chamomile” is a quote from Thousand and One Arabian Nights. we live, & grow weary of Love, & ride to war & boast & grow weary with age.

This Arabian poetry with Josephus
Josephus: Flavius Josephus was a writer who lived at the time of Herod, Governor of Galilee, Initially he was against Roman rule, he eventually became a Roman citizen. He wrote about the Jewish war (75-79AD) and the dynasty of Herod., will, I think stand “back of Herod,” as [Reueus?] and Aristophanes
Aristophanes: A celebrated comic poet from Ancient Athens. stood back of “A Messiah.”
We are living divinely great days. Henry is in a cloud. I increase in vision – vision too of all that leaps in the heart. Imaginative speech is however growing difficult to me.
A beautiful direct [????] gown is completed. This paid for & is perfect: in that direction – peace.

On Friday

div.p:
I continue Fay’s visit – He came up, fussed as to wh: room we should sit in - was commanded into the sitti Sun room, & then he told how Rodin
Auguste René Rodin 1840 –1917 was a well-known and highly respected French sculptor. He became President of the International Society of Sculptors, Painters and Gravers, of London after James Abbott McNeill Whistler died. heard that Shannon
Charles Haslewood Shannon (1863 -1937) was an English artist and life partner of Charles Ricketts. Both were close friends of Edith and Katharine. admired the torso of his St. John Baptist (as a study) shown at the International & offered it through a third person in exchange for a picture by Shannon. It was as if Francis Joseph the oldest Royal Person in Europe, of the oldest race, had offered an <order> old (“The Golden Fleece”?) to Shannon. It was like the Renaissance. Rodin is the oldest monarch of art among the most artistic people of Europe.

The Shannon pictures are the artistic triumph of the exhibition – The Deuil Marin of Cottet
Charles Cottet, a painter who exhibited at the International Society of Sculptors, Painters and Gravers, of London. is the social triumph & the Spaniard Zulodga
Ignacio Zuloaga y Zabaleta (1870 -1945) was a Basque (Spanish province) painter who lived in London for a brief period before returning to Spain to General Franco’s nationalistic party during the Spanish Revolution. He painted Franco’s portrait in 1940. the popular triumph. Fay catches sight of The Century
The Century Magazine: was an illustrated monthly magazine, published in London. Volume LXVII, New Series: Vol. XLV contained an illustrated article about Isabella Gardner’s Museum. with pictures of Mrs. Gardener’s
Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, Massachusetts was completed in 1903. Palace of Art & some of its treasures. He sends congratulations to Bernard
Bernard Berenson, 1865 – 1959 was a hugely successful American art historian specializing in the Renaissance. Edith, Katherine and Bernard enjoyed an “aesthetically sexual” relationship through poetry and letters. that he bought the Holbein <Dürer> & knew it as Holbein <Dürer> if the face had been unstippled It wd have been the 3rd or 4th in importance – even as it is it is about 7th . Fay has always called the

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 26; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793; fol. 12v, Wendy Walter and Jenée Crayne

div.p: picture his Holbein - <Dürer> – because when shown at the old masters no one had the penetration or courage to support him in his certainty it was a Holbein <Dürer>.

Tho’ announced the book on Raphael
Raffaello Sanzio da Urbino 1483-1520, known as Raphael was a famous Italian painter and architect of the Renaissance. will not be written.. It wd provoke the hostility of all camps – for Guilio Romano
Romano: A Pupil of Raphael. decreases & Raphael increases & most of what Morelli
Morelli: This might be a reference to Domenico Morelli, 1823–1901 an Italian painter, who was immensely influential in the arts of the second half of the 19th century, both as director of the Accademia di Belle Arti in Naples, but also because of his rebelliousness against institutions. said is unsaid or would be. I ask him to dine with us next Tuesday & he departs leaving me weary, & sore vexed to hear Michael’s ring a moment or two later.
Friday Jan. 16th
To turn in [sunned?] coldness –

at the Carfax
Carfax: Carfax Gallery: The Carfax Gallery was founded in 1899 by William Rothenstein and John Fothergill. we look round at the Blakes, having been made to pay toll of it for a Catalogue. Bobbie Ross
Bobbie Ross= Robert Ross (1869-1918) a dealer at the Carfax Gallery (http://www.19thc-artworldwide.org/fletcher/london-gallery/data/pages/as524.htm) Robert Baldwin "Robbie" Ross (25 May 1869 – 5 October 1918) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robbie_Ross) soon comes to us & presses to return the toll. He is humorous as a dog is good. tempered – on a natural & noble scale. He shows us the admired of – Shannon “Bathsheba at the Bath”– “The Bard from Gray

div.p:
cover a Universe with its ridged field of waters. There is an Entombment – very simple, with a light before the black veils of the mourners – There is an Ascension, where the springing form, with aerial colour in it, is seen from the back. Ross thinks this figure unconsciously suggested Fay’s

old Charon, leaning on his oar,
Waits for my coin. Go thou before, and leave
me to my crucifix,. Upstairs is the gem – as of course the perfect [????] of all. judging Fay has pronounced on it – The River of Life
The River of Life: Watercolor by William Blake: The River of Life c.1805 Ink and watercolour on paper Image: 305 x 336 mm support: 442 x 432 mm. This work illustrates lines from the Book of Revelation. The River of Life flows from the throne of God to the Tree of Life. PROVENANCE (history of ownership): Thomas Butts; Thomas Butts jun.; Capt. Capt. F.J. Butts was the owner of the watercolor at the time of the viewing by Michael Field. lovely water-colour. What deliciousness to swim through meadow–lands on that stream – in flight with its flying crystal – with flutists piping your sylvan salvation, & the air a tapestry of the fruit of life! And such a light in the sky – yellow as sun setting before it is sundown & while there is not any sadness in it. For the rest Blake had a repugnant effect on the eyes that had not seen him for many years & among the hideousness of nightmare it seemed quite sane to hear Bobby giving an account of all the mad murderers at Broadmore
Broadmore: The hospital was first known as the Broadmoor Criminal Lunatic Asylum. It was built to a design by Sir Joshua Jebb, an officer of the Corps of Royal Engineers, and covered 53 acres (210,000 square metres) within its secure perimeter. The first patient was a female admitted for infanticide on 27 May 1863.. [????] murderer seemed to think

div.p: we <he> had been just a little hasty – & a man who had cut the throats of his wife & many children had made a stained glass window for the chapel on the subject, ‘suffer the little children to come unto me & forbid them not.’ Fay has refused, like me, to believe – but Bobby swears as if he were in chapel. The governor had never seen anything re-markable in the window. Bobby is to come to us on Septuagesima Sunday & he actually has wit to see the humor that lurks in such an intention!
The Dentist chops to my nerve – but promises no-more ice-brook pangs. –

Off to the International. All Shannon’s pictures look more beautiful than in the studio – They & the beauteous Symphony in White
Symphony in White: “Symphony in White, No. 111”: The 4th Exhibition of International Art/The International Society of Sculptors, Painters and Gravers was held at New Gallery January 1904 “Symphony in White, No. lll” lent by Edmund Davis., with together with the Valparaiso
Valparaiso: “Crepuscule in Flesh Colour and Green: Valparaiso” 1866; By Whistler, James Abbott McNeill., of Whistler
Whistlers: James Abbott McNeill; American Painter, 1834 – 1903. are the things of beauty there. Fay’s profound Entombment Burial is high – he angerly calls it Skied – it is too high, & a vile study by a young woman of a white mousy young woman chalks the eye sight ascending gravely. – The Committee should be taken out & shot for such

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 29; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 14r; Jenée Crayne

div.p:
an insult. Shannon has spoken his mind to the Scotchmen of The Butter-Scotch Club
The Butter-Scotch Club: tentatively it could be referring to the Glasgow Boys of the Glasgow School., as he sardonically calls it.
We came on Shannon wandering – with his lovely gait, his drawn cheek. He takes us to the pictures & he talks with reanimating eyes.

Suddenly – “There is the monster” & Fay siddles from the pictures in a white ill-mood. He has written he cannot come on Tuesday & has proposed Wednesday. The Rodin– Shannon exchange has been bungled & turned to exasperating issues by the influence of ‘so many others’ –––– We see the torso
Sculpture titled Torso by F. Derwent Wood.; it is lean & vigorous as archaic Greek work. Fay takes Michael to his likes & his dear dislikes – storming. wavily on the Rodin subject – Latin rage deep in his eyes. Shannon & I talk the Palace Pictures – a theme I am not laggard at. We soothe – we are nicely dressed Michael delicious in the directoire hat – & the occasion prospers. They have to leave us for a business interview at the Carfax.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 30; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 14v; Jenée Crayne

div.p: Friday, Saturday – Sunday – I go out. I fill my being with air & the cold glory of the North aspect of the wind.
Then Monday – all melted putrefaction of the Spring.
But such great days with Herod & Mariamne – our Arab & Jewess. Our imaginations have to toil like Explorers – We are Exhausted to stupification stone at night with the effort.

p.hi: Tuesday - Jan 19th.

div.p:
By chance I open The Times to see & my heart rushes on the track of my eyes – that Arthur Strong
Strong, Sandford Arthur (1863-1904) London, United Kingdom, Librarian and Arabic scholar; helped identify and catalog masterworks in British collections. is dead. Relief for Bernhard
Berenson, Bernard. is my immediate feeling – the cruel enemy, who had boasted he would utterly crush him in England – gone into the forbidding absolute of silence! Then I rush to Michael & we feel together the curious pain, as at the loss of a thing of value, that we always knew we should feel when the unknown Strong passed. Would we could have met him once! Frailty – scholarship (For

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 31; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 15r; Jenée Crayne

div.p:
wh: women always have a yearning devoutness – a humanism, an inhuman tongue – a face like Erasmus’
Desiderius Erasmus of Rotterdam (1467?–1536) was the most famous and influential humanist of the Northern Renaissance, a man of great talent and industriousness who rose from obscure beginnings to become the leading intellectual figure of the early sixteenth century, courted by rulers and prelates who wanted to enhance their own reputations by association with the greatest scholar of the age. – he had lure … & therefore doom is realised in his having died.
Alice Trusted writes –

“There is always some scarce spectacle in the valley that fills me with awe like aerial things are want to do. On the 11th it was a rainbow that shifted from the sky & hung on the golden elms, for the cluster was still arrayed with foliage above the convent. The colours strengthened, waned & brightened. Picture these prismatic hues alighting & [????] several moments on gold. As the rainbow faded a gentle shower fell. Not any wind was stirring through the valley & the rain drops, clearer than pearls lingered on the fringe of these golden leaves in the falling.” Pater
Pater: Walter Pater, in full Walter Horatio Pater (born August 4, 1839, Shadwell, London, England—died July 30, 1894, Oxford, Oxfordshire) English critic, essayist, and humanist whose advocacy of “art for art’s sake” became a cardinal doctrine of the movement known as Aestheticism. would have god–fathered this catching or seizure of a moment.

Mary
Mary Berenson, Art Historian, Art Critic, Writer and Lecturer, a scholar of Italian Renaissance art, was the collaborator and wife of Bernard Berenson. writes of a woman’s lunch at Boston, & how a lady, who is writing an article up on pictures of Circe ( she cd. not imagine herself one

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 32; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 15v; Jenée Crayne

div.p:
as she resembled an animated rag-bag) wanted to embrace Mary’s knees when she heard she knew Duse
Eleonora Duse born Oct. 3, 1858 was an Italian actress. –– she said she had done it to a lady who had been in Samoa with Stevenson
Robert Louis Stevenson .
She continues ^

“William Yeats gave a rather silly but nice lecture – in manner & looks he is a cross between [Trevy?] & Roger
Roger Eliot Fry (14 December 1866 – 9 September 1934) was an English painter and critic, and a member of the Bloomsbury Group. Mary and Bernard, along with Robert Dell, Herbert Cook, Roger Fry and Herbert Horne, had a crucial role in the creation of the Burlington, the first issue of which was published in 1903.. . . after the reception the ‘Circe’ lady brought up her daughter for Mr. Yeats to kiss on the forehead, so that the girl could remember all her life she had been kissed by a poet – He seemed pleased though, & he told me he was making more money than he had ever made before in his life. He is going to California & has 20 more lectures to give.”
Didn’t we find he liked the wealth!

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 33; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 16r; Ayah Hamed Falatah

div.p: Wednesday Jan. 20th
The Artists came out of the fog to dine - again not beautiful as diners should be - but they plead the frightful weather and indeed the star Earth is getting a terrible place to live in.

Michael wears her black striped silk Directoire with [fischu?] of ivory net darned with green and bowed with green velvet – a scarf of black crêpe with under fruits of green. I wear the Manchu necklace y on my old gold blouse.

p.hi: Menu

div.p: Orleans soup
Cod à la créme
Hare (roasted)
Plum pudding & zabajone
Canapés de S.Iral
White port & old dry Lisbon.

The dinner is, our guests say, “beautiful” – We have good stories to tell from America – but... there is Fay’s hard prejudice against Herod & the Arabs, & there is the dark abysm of Strong’s death – these to us spoil the evening. Manlike, Fay skims the gulf elaborately-yet once or twice I catch on him that curious, consternating beauty

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 34; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 16v; Ayah Hamed Falatah

div.p: that seems to burgeon with the thought of death. The subtle heightening that love gives to the appearance of an animal - so that its hair is more toyful, its colour more pricking to the sense, & in its motions it lingers & yet is pregnant with charm sparkle - this subtilty of effect the thought of death evokes in Fay & makes him lovely under it.

The only really good story he tells is of Bobby Ross at Edinburgh - during a literary gathering that discussed Shakespeare’s sonnets. And elder of the kirk deplored the deep blot on what would have been a blameless reputation. "But perhaps after all Shakespeare meant no harm" said Bobby weakly & it happened that just at that moment the cock crow three times.

The idea that Cockerell had leant <lent> us Lady Anne Blunt’s Arabic poetry seemed to chafe Fay -and even Shannon turned abusive.. Fay called our strip of old Persian rug “Cockerellian” to punish us & then a cloud came round the god, chilly and [mumping?]

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 35; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 17r; Ayah Hamed Falatah

div.p: - yet at moments <whiles> vaporous as if about an altar. So he went, with cold fingers - mortally cold adieux.
the day after the artists have dined with us, I write to Painter.
You are painting to-day, -you are as a bee at her honey. I can speak to you.

You can listen to one or two of my songs about shells - & a sonnet, & another. I have chosen, but who knows how wisely, for the poet cannot choose, or distinguish one song from another. Comfort yourself with anything you like in these dateless fragments, & forget the rest.

We are happy this morning in a big moth-[brain?] Josephus. We have just read how Cleopatra entreated Herod <Antony> to give her Judea & Arabia. These were the ages when one could play with life, & toss the nations about in the hollow of one's hand. It's foolish, Painter, to infer into my joy in these great Jews & heathens.
Let this sentence convert you. "Then were their glorious vessels carried into captivity.
- there is a verse to move you!
Michael

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 36; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 17v; Ayah Hamed Falatah

div.p: The poems I send are -
Camellias - Onycha II. "Heralds there are of love, the dusky flock.’’ “Forever” & the lovely shepherd
Friday. Bitter fog.
I write

Better it were that ball on finest wires frail Jenny Wren
Jenny Wren is a character from Charles Dickens’ Our Mutual Friend should perish of the cold in the thick rime afar from winter fires, Far from the crumbs that in my hands I hold, far better than the murder I have done, letting thee see the verse that I have writ, too deft, too delicate the couplets run, subtle in fancy, tender but in wit.- thou wilt not freeze them, that is not my fear - Terror will strike them dead against the breast, and very [????] thou wilt make their [bier?] and the bare ground, instead of woven nest. O sorrow that a woman must not speak save in pure symbol from the lip, the cheek.
It is Saturday - Jan 23rd. More bitter fog.

I strive a candle & by a tallow- fog light to read an Arabian ode, & a chapter of Josephus. It is awful to think of a studio in the light of tallow fog also. We cannot pass in or out. Strong is in his grave, the whole world is a grave above his grave -We are shut up: on the line there are accidents - "Bellina"
Bellina Strong is Arthur Strong’s wife. is a widow now.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 37; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 18r; Ayah Hamed Falatah

div.p: I write

I have left thee - Was our parting at the grave? So wide it seems, nothing there is that dooms and no impediment; I am seeking thee, as from the river-head one seeks the sea, ever thou art, ever affronting me,
And the moon blooms.
Apple Sunday - Jan 24th
Our Milton is very wonderful this morning - Adam's appeal to his Creator for a fellow - Heaven's sly response - the male understanding - the perfect union of the angels.
I come to Herod's story - to the great chapter of the apple & the knife - I have read this before - now I write it.
Heaven be praised. What precious stones have been set in this baleful January!
In the afternoon - it is again the South wind that does it - Henry's brain opens its windows, & the scenario. Joseph. Mariamne - the Sous-Antipater of the play is built up.
the fog's gone; there is no sunlight - but we have been greatly visited, greatly blest.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 38; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 18v; Hao Hoang Nguyen

div.p: Tues Jan. 26th

We go on damp ground to town - only for shopping & a dental appointment. We see Whittaker Wright
James Whitaker Wright (1846-1904). A former printer, Methodist minister, and a company promoter and swindler. On January 26th 1904, Wright was convicted of fraud and given a seven-year prison sentence. He then committed suicide. has been condemned to 7 years penal servitude. There is a rush along of news boys.

p.hi: He is dead.

div.p:
The charm of the man was the velocity of the immense stream of his ideal idealism. It drew into its own current. The scale of it lured reason itself – reason that Tommy
Tommy: Thomas Sturge Moore (1870-1944), an English poet, author, and artist. declares in his own paper on
Proportion (Montly Review of the [Month?]) to be the antagonist if all know forces other than itself &therefore its most essential character is the hope & desire to control & transform the universe?
Whittaker Wright perfected his universe and consented to let it exist on the condition of dreaming it in millions.

Nothing lures & touches men so much as a great scale. A man in the court is reported to have murmured "He's had thousands mine, but, upon my soul, I could cry to see 'such and ending to such a career.”

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 39; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 19r; Hao Hoang Nguyen

div.p: [E.C]
During <the last day of the> the trial he was doomed or had doomed himself to death. “It was as if the inner soul of the man was living more rapidly than the body could follow.”
After he was dead, six bare-headed officials bore the convict’s coffin, & a little knot of men removed their hats & helmets – he had become the representative of Death’s Empire.

Tommy’s Idea of Proportion is full of fresh things said with many pebbles in the mouth. He has hit on my parallel between artist & saint. He puts it excellently - “both are convinced, neither understands.” Tommy also thinks the thought of Bernhard
Bernard Berenson (1865-1959) that Art can give Peace when the imagination has trained reason to see a friend in her enemy – the physical order, & “we spell out from that wh: Nature presents to us, the desired word, the congenial” – as Göethe
Johann Wolfgang (von) Goethe (1749 – 1832) says.
That incarnate dream from Egypt, I have cut out, finds something “congenial” in the Korean Post-Master. I am grateful that nature made him.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 40; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 19v; Hao Hoang Nguyen

div.p: Finely carved youthful figure of Khonsu: believed to be a portrait of Hor’m’heb, Eighteenth Dynasty. From the Temple of Khonsu.
Min Sang Ho, the postmaster-general of Korea, is a native who has been educated in America.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 41; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 20r; Hao Hoang Nguyen

div.p: [E.C]
Now I must return to Monday January 25th.
[K.B]
Sabbatai – the ring - day

Painters
Painters: Nickname for Charles Shannon. comes from ice of a [train-top?] – we talk quietly over the fire in the gold – room till he thaws. He puts aside the Lettere da Siena.. for a little while – afterwards: “there are 2 of the poems I greatly like...one might have been in the Shakespeare sonnets, & it appears to me rather taller than some of his... He suggests designing for me a little writing-table.

Tea – then it is announced the ring in its first modelling is here – It is a gigantic ring, as Painter says “one of the largest rings in the world. We lay it on his Baudelaire
Baudelaire: Charles Pierre Baudelaire (1821-1867), a French poet. with the pendant: he gazes at his work. They are 2 very beautiful objects.
He is persuaded to stay to dinner & the time goes smoothly & naturally.

If I were a poet he has said to me, I should treat of disillusion. Chopin
Frédéric François Chopin (1810 – 1849), a Polish composer and virtuoso pianist of the Romantic era. is full of a glittering irony. Even in painting he wd like to give something of disillusion. But his great desire in painting is to express compassion.
Henry reads to him several of my sonnets, while I am in a cloud of cigarette – smoking, puffing

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 42; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 20v; Hao Hoang Nguyen

div.p: [K.B]

out my hist atmosphere at <by> the balcony - window. I am well started now on this path of abstract passion I have chosen – the air is rather fine & [???] & I suffer, and can repeat nothing of what is going on around me.
[E.C]

Alice Trusted writes deliciously of St. [???] “There has been rime in the valley for a few days; The gentlest breeze would have shattered the en-chantment & not a breath stirred. Picture Castle Dimas with an even mantle of hoar frost & the land-scape, soft, sunny & soothing: a flaxen light falling upon the waves of the little Path.”

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 43; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 21r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: My version of Jan. 25 – Monday.

When I come into tea Fay
Fay is a nickname for Charles de Sousy Ricketts (2 October 1866 – 7 October 1931), English artist, illustrator, author and printer. Friend of Michael Field and partner of Charles Shannon. is thawing – he has promised, I hear, to be very nice when he has thawed. On the side-table are the sonnets in their Italian cover. Fay is recalcitrant over mustard & cress – in a sandwich the second bite of them is corrupt as the taste – but when he finds them embalmed in the new Gentleman’s Relish
Gentleman’s Relish: A type of anchovy paste also known as Patum Peperium. - the [bellamy?]-like hand of the Fay catches at several. During tea we hear more of Bobby Ross
Bobby Ross: Robert Baldwin Ross (25 May 1869 – 5 October 1918), art critic. & receive charges for the occasion of his visit. We are con-vinced that Bobby is being so elaborately sent in order to savour our “legend” & then to spread its charming meshes - dyed in the rays of Fay’s glory. Bobby has the fabulous lips, touched with the light of humour, that can assure a tradition. While I am lighting the sun-room (it is on the verge of a flood of white-washing & only contains some fresh-cold tulips that wave cleanly) Fay suggests that he will design a table (if possible) to stand under the picture & support the pale flower that is of ritual beneath it.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 44; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 21v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: When Michael & he reach the sun-room now divided between the open twilight & the struggling candle-light Fay proposes that the sonnets be read aloud. Something this side of the perfectly abstract makes him say “Let your fellow read” & I put on the whole armour of the abstract, securing every buckle, & read Ochyn Onycha wh: he had thought was not quite [uni?] where it passed from the flower to the shell. My voice converts him.
I concluded
“And of the busy brain left desolate” - without parting. Michael has been standing in blackness against the twilit window & her cigarette was is vaporous for her screen.
Then I read Cammellias – but this is even too long.

Finally I read, by the mantel-shelf The Shepherd of the Wild. He greatly praises the great exposition of the first line – a master’s way of beginning; but he objects to “O love, o mystery” as weak in effect I complain “if we are to have no statements & no interjections, what are we to have?” He only likes interjections when they are purely instructive & have no trace

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 45; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 22r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: of formalism or of the literary. Verlaine’s are perhaps the most perfect. “O toi “Qu’as tu fait, o toi que voilà,
De ta jeunesse?”
There is nothing considered about them.

All this time we have been cold as moonbeams - he has been as inquisitive as a moonbeam into the art of these love-poems. Yet all through the evening there is that <such> jeweled satisfaction about his aspect that <as> makes the [laurentine?] resemble the [lovely?] myrtle itself, in a very wide sense.

Suddenly we learn the Sabbatai Ring is come in its first state - or is brought out, with its doors & spotted dome, its buttresses & its windows, through wh: a loose emerald flashes with ranging green & the tinkle of it is heard like a God inside. What fancy assails & prompts one in this strange inward life of sound & flesh from their prison! It is a wicked way if making beauty court on the sly when she has conquered by frank design & ornament. Yet the courting beauty, though transparently wicked, is utterly delightful & Fay’s joy in it is

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 46; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 22v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: as a [????]’s joy in the rustling laughter he evokes.

The ring Fay would like to be ready for Sunday & indeed there is in it an inherent legendary element to be wished for Bobby’s attention. It sits on Michael’s finger like a blue falcon, soft & indifferent to any suffering. It does not care for the blasphemers – it sits invested in dignity.

Indeed as it lies on Boudelaire
Charles Pierre Baudelaire (April 9, 1821 – August 31, 1867), a French poet ,essayist and art critic with the pendant I cannot wonder that their author finds them most beautiful.

Fay has been feeling his life [shrink?] - he must read Shakespeare. We speak of Troilus & Cressida– he writhes with excess of pleasure in it. Then we press him to stay & dine, winning his acceptance when we promise a telegram to Shannon
Charles Haslewood Shannon (26 April 1863 – 18 March 1937). & a nice dinner, though the cook is out.

During its course we mostly talk of Mary
Mary: Mary Berenson (1864 – 1945), née Mary Smith, art historian. Wife of Bernard Berenson, friend of Michael Field & Berenson
Bernard Berenson (June 26, 1865 – October 6, 1959), an American art historian. who are now at Chicago, visiting pork-kings & steel kings! Some with houses that suggest an orgy – some with Japanese servants who lecture at the University on social science & philology on their evenings out. One

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 47; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 23r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p:
magnate of the meat-market disbelieves in war between Russia & Japan
The Russo-Japanese War (8 February 1904 – 5 September 1905) was fought between the Russian Empire and the Empire of Japan over rival imperial ambitions in Manchuria and Korea. just because the orders are not such as accompany the extreme cause.
The Fairy man takes [daintly?] & with content his soup, roast lamb, junket & damson tart.

Then upstairs over coffee great talk begins – only to be broken by arrival of model blouses? that must be seen & immediately returned by the bearer. We, in ivory net & black velvet, is confirmed to me, with a few sharp edged <eyed> improvements of a value scarcely believable. Outside the messenger steals my money & departs with it.

Then we talk of delusion. It is to him the poetry of what remains – of the pot pourri, of the light after sunset, of love when passion is gone, often of religion. <It is what remains of [precious?] in the ashes.> He would love to give it in music. Baudelaire gave it in literature. Rossetti
Christina Georgina Rossetti (5 December 1830 – 29 December 1894) in the [????] [????] has touched it beautifully, but it is a very rare theme.

Baudelaire is brought – he reads in his rapid French too rapid to be transparent to one’s understanding, several of his <Baudelaire’s> most cherished poems: L’Aube Spirituelle.
L’Aube Spirituelle: tr. “The Spiritual Dawn,” a poem by Charles Baudelaire Le Cr (specially

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 48; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 23v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p:
dwelling on the marvellous phrase “stupides orgies”) & Crépuscule du Matin
Crépuscule du Matin: tr. “Morning Crepescule,” a poem by Charles Baudelaire (full of pity – that most rare quality in art) & La Rebelle.
La Rebelle: tr. “The Rebel,” a poem by Charles Baudelaire
The last 4 lines of the Crépescule ought to have been omitted.

The greatest of Baudelaire’s poems is La Géante
La Géante: tr. “The Giantess,” a poem by Charles Baudelaire – the vast impersonality that denies its very sex, everything & expresses itself in a form so vast & yet plastic. It is perhaps one of the most remarkable things man has done.

Next to it comes La Beauté
La Beauté: tr. “The Beauty,” a poem by Charles Baudelaire – then L’Aube Spirituelle – then Femmes Damnées
Femmes Damnées: tr. “Women Doomed,” a poem by Charles Baudelaire (without its last exclamatory verse).

Just before the reading of Baudelaire I had read Tommy’s
Thomas Sturge Moore Don Juan
“Don Juan in Hell” is a poem written by Charles Ricketts in 1908 loud – first to the entreaty I wd leave out the iterated Don Juan then to the entreaty I would leave off altogether. Fay sprang up, [????] & declaring the childish – almost infamous in taste. Don Juan is a grand gentleman – the type of the debauché wh: gives the world vast pleasure & takes on himself almost the pains of a saint; a creature enjoyed as a saint is worshipped almst for his idealism. He would make the world nearer to the heart’s desire –

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 49; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 24r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: & Don Juan faced damnation for his dreams – he never recoiled fearful…& then to be told he wore silk stockings & they stuck out under his cloak when the dance was ended by Death – Tommy ought to be birched.

Baudelaire’s Don Juan aux Enfers with its magnificent last lines – "Mais le calme héros, courbé sur sa rapière, Regardait le sillage et ne daignait rien voir" is far more, though not wholly, adequate.

Then talk goes to the meeting with Bernhard and the friendship with Oscar
Oscar Fingal O'Flahertie Wills Wilde (16 October 1854 – 30 November 1900), an Irish playwright, novelist, essayist, and poet. Fay says they and Oscar never talked anything but inspired “rot”. As women, we probably have no idea how playful men are among themselves. Fay said scarcely anything – nothing serious – Oscar tried all his newest paradoxes on them elaborated exciting, fantastic projects. Before dinner, I had shown Fay our two letters from Oscar & delighted him specially with Oscar’s desire to see our characters in golden masques (we are to show these letters to Bobby – as two bricks in “the legend.”)

Then we <have> fine merry times over the artists’ Orders – over the Cochon d’Or
Cochon d’Or: tr. “Golden Pig”. That we lay for in vain “avec soif

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 50; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 24v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p:
inassouvie”.
Avec soif inassouvie: tr. “with unquenched thirst” No hope of it in paragon! Only Sappho can have it among women, & she partly from politeness.

Baudelaire wd have all the orders - Cochon d’Or – L’Oiseau bleu
L’Oiseau bleu: tr. “The Blue Bird” & Couronne des Épines.
Couronne des Épines: tr. “Crown of Thorns” The last Fay thought I might have, with a few thorns added from time to time for delapidations – Michael refuses L’Oiseau bleu, even with 4 wings & confesses on her death-bed she means to wring Fay’s heart to give her the Cochon d’Or.
Keats is very difficult to decorate – he ought to have all the orders & they none of them have quite fit.
Shakespeare – Michael denies him the Cochon d’Or – he is too much like herself. But Fay says yes, for the sake of Troilus & Mid-Summer Night’s Dream and such things as

“Her bed is Judia & herself a pearl” – “My God what a fluke!” – he wrings his hands with Cochon d’Or ecxtasy. Bobby may be made an associate. Moore has no Cochon d’Or in him – nor we have to protest had Browning enough for the order – dissent too

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 51; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 25r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: shrewdly fretted the golden floor of nature, the Cochon d’Or must have. Shannon has to have it and because he is a fellow divinest by the grand master Ricketts – Mary Berenson might have the hope dangled before her – if she would induce some meat-kings to buy it at an enormous price.
The sm badge is a golden pig, with a pearl in his mouth & the legend Sweets to the Sweet.
Ah me - - - ah, me! - ah, ah me!
The Crown of Thorns is only for those who struggle & agonize for art’s own sake – the Oiseau bleu is for the chosen spirits of culture and art – those who are rare & charming in personality.
On this fun we part – after 6 hours of converse & scarcely tired.
Shannon thinks Fay “forgiving” – we assure him he is the contrary – wh: Fay supports by saying of his enemies “I take the air from them.”
Fay has looked beautiful at times, with a crested & lively appearance.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 52; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 25v; Stephen Lagos

div.p: Fay quotes for richness, such as ever literature used to have, [????] “tender crumbs” – of the dust of a body.
On Saturday even Jan 30th after a long week of disorder. Whitewashes and [rabs?] – not pictures on the walls, we are at work again i.e. we are in our rooms, we pace. Oh the re-lighting of the altars!
A shrine where the blasphemers have left marks!
Four times I seek flowers -
White, sepulchral with arums –
The air cannot float a [wing?]

Four times with bitter rain [????] me to the flesh. I wrestle—by candle—light time - with Lady- apples, with Love apples, with tulips “in answerable style,” & the red – [????] of P
P is a nickname for Edith Cooper. [settia?]-life is established visible among us. The first flickering narcissus flickers on the shrine. A periwinkle with Trickling—wreathes hang outside the casement of the lesser gold room.
Love-Apple Sunday
I review the month. We have fought well in it, facing many things. Now we must face the publisher. Our mottos of diligence & [????] must continue. The pine & [????] scent

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 53; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 26r; Stephen Lagos

div.p: must come as they will - they will be scents across the battlefield.

God knows that where He plants the foot on the sand, He must set the mirage. It is the absence of a little cloud before that is making life so difficult now. One cannot be looking down on the sand one is treading.
We turn again to Herod, to the Creation of Cleopatra.
February 3rd
Days large & blank with spring. I am weary even of my prayers. No call from Heaven on earth—I go a’shopping. but mercy I say to myself: “why should one buy stockings, if one has not happy feet?”

Maccabees
Maccabees – leaders of a Jewish rebel army that took over Judea which had been part of the Seleucid Empire at the time. we are reading in the morning miserable & wordy & of no account with here & there an unforgettable phrase. Rossetti’s

What is it?—not the letter of [such?]-plight,

What is it?—not the signet of a king, nor deep—inscribed, nor holy, perfumed ring. With phial for the venoms that [requite?].
