Fay was a nickname for Charles de Sousy Ricketts (1866 -1931), a versatile English artist, illustrator, author and printer. was fresh-shaven, & had the bleak appearance of our East wind. Late a count–arrived, a well-bred personage, full of earful tact. The speech was formal; but the eyes need not be formal, even with strangers.

Tall & injured by illness & suffering Helen Fry
Helen (Coombe) Fry was married to Roger Eliot Fry, an English painter and critic, and a member of the Bloomsbury Group came in to Miss Toplady’s
Miss Toplady’s was an American Lady’s Shop in London specializing in furniture, china, and old jewels. yesterday.
Very swiftly she said she was going to pray –
Ah, would it were [????] us! Would indeed we all went forth to

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 79; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 39r; Nancy Capone Beeman

div.p: confess & be shriven, & to pray.
Worship as spectators – without the crocked knee & the contrite heart – without the real, personal sacrifice – is disinterprately?
We do not meditate, or pray, or believe...God keep us in our little home; it is inexpressibly dear to us, & we ask to live no where else.

I must supplement this time, from what Michael
Michael was a nickname used by Edith Cooper for Katherine Bradley. told me by the fireside.

Fay is “woolly” & ill. He might have been seen that morning running from the Marble Arch to his book-shop for an Anatole France
Anatole France (1844-1924) was a French poet, journalist, and novelist., running though he felt ill. He returned also with a bottle of Baltic herrings – “Would you like to see them?” They appear; & Michael remarks “they are as beautiful as precious stones” They lie silvering round the sides of the bottle, in white wine, with corals & pink sea-weed, as it were, a’shimmer between. Anatole France gives him great delight, though he knows in ten years the books will be intolerable. “Oh yes, you are so strictly contemporaneous now” scolds Michael.

He brings out portraits of Mrs. Richard Green & Mrs. Hacon
Mrs. Hacon: The Lady with the Green Fan (portrait of Mrs. Hacon) by Charles Haslewood Shannon (1863-1937).. He rejoices in Michael’s remark that Mrs. Hacon

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 80; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 39v; Nancy Capone Beeman

div.p: has a beauty as if born of itself like true apple-ness of the apple. She has also that great mark of beauty the breaking of the lips into flower.
Discussing women’s beauty, Michael says that eyebrows are the most important point in the face for appearance.
Fay assents & rejoins that any woman if she arranges her hair properly, takes care of her eyebrows & tries to have a bit of black velvet at her neck will look well.

Michael repeats praise of Shannon’s
Shannon: Charles Haslewood Shannon, an English artist (1863-1937). portrait. “Shannon always did appeal to the vulgar taste of the vulgar” Fay gibes.
He has to confess he will have no pictures ready for the spring – not till winter. O Fay, frittered Fay!

He opens a box by Korin
Korin: Ogata Kōrin (1658-1716) was a Japanese painter of the Rinpa school. – “full of Illusion & Disillusion” . . . .

The little ball of ambergris & two opals given by Michael and some designs for Omar
Omar: Possibly in reference to Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyám, the title that Edward FitzGerald gave to his translation of a selection of poems, originally written in Persian and numbering about a thousand, attributed to Omar Khayyám (1048-1131), a Persian poet, mathematician and astronomer..
Michael pleads that the opals are not disillusion & is referred to the unused set of designs for Omar.
Mrs. Tommy’s pendant is on view –

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 81; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 40r; Nancy Capone Beeman

div.p:
it has been drawn out a success by its marvellous little inventor. The modelling of Psyche
The name of a mortal woman in Greek mythology, who becomes the wife of Eros. & the Dog of Hell
Dog of Hell: In Greek mythology, Cerberus, often called the "hound of Hades,” is a monstrous multi-headed dog, who guards the gates of the underworld. is magnificent – the effect is gorgeous.

[Birny’s?]
Birny: Possibly in reference to Bernard Berenson (1865-1959), an American art historian specializing in the Renaissance. bride only has a Holbein Pendant
Holbein Pendant: Pendant, with a lady holding a stone, and three hanging pearls, one of three designs for jewellery with inscriptions, from the ‘Jewellery Book.’ – this is well. [Birny?] is to the true poet what an adopted design is to a created one.

When the Count comes there is talk of Fay’s birthplace – Geneva. The Count proposes as a game to find the place where each ought to have been born. Fay had a narrow escape of being born at the right place – Naples. Michael would like to have been born in London. Fay says “that is where a poet should be born”.
The rapidity of the river at [Basle?] is mentioned. Michael says the rushing of a river along gives her the sense of perfect repose.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 82; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, 40v; Nancy Capone Beeman

div.p: We have had a card from Tommy in Rome. He thought of us at the Borgia apartments where he went not with subtle poisons

“To thin the scarlet conclave of old men”
Excerpted from the John Keats’ epic poem, “The Fall of Hyperion: A Dream,” sometimes subtitled as “A Vision” instead of a dream. but to stare at Pinturicchio’s
Pinturicchio: Bernardino di Betto, called Pintoricchio or Pinturicchio (1454–1513) was an Italian painter of the Renaissance. He acquired his nickname, Pintoricchio ("little painter"), because of his small stature, and he used it to sign some of his works. pretty, mellow frescoes. He picked a leaf & violet-bud off Keats’ grave for us – “that is if you have not already got several. It is a delicious spot, covered by violets, shaded by beautiful pines & ilex-bushes & strange with stone-monuments, looking at one another like foreigners with different tongues but the same thoughts & business . . . Woe, I must out with it! I met Arthur Symons yesterday. Duse
Eleonora Duse: An Italian actress (1858-1924), often known simply as Duse. has accepted a play of his on Tristan & Isolde
Tristan & Isolde: An opera, or music drama, in three acts by Richard Wagner. & is going to begin to study in it in May. I felt so angry with him. We also thought of you “at the baths of Caracalla.
It is well to be thought of in Rome. O blessed O Empire of our imagination! - Than <Even> if Duse takes Symons’ Tristan – Little Arthur, who lifted me up to see the Procession in Notre Dame de Paris!

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 83; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 41r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: March 2nd, Wednesday. S. Chad’s Day
Henry has read to me the scene at luncheon between Herod & Salome – the waiting for Mariamne’s death. It is level up with Othello. It has made March already a month of huge experience

And there is verdure & quickening green all [????] the smaller scenes. More & more the story is frightening to the throttling love-grip of Mariamne. Herod’s passion in its curse, its cheeks, its headlong fall into the sea – the theme. He asked the Infinite in his affections, the infinite of Woman, Child & God. He was infinite in praise and in the art of praise-building. His memory built in monuments.
The vacant memory of regret he could not bear, _ that is why he carried Mariamne about with his [embalmment?].
In Herod I create myself Man – the make of Herod’s nature is mine.
How wonderful Heaven is to us – setting us on the track, giving us the clue to its hid treasure –

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 84; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 41v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: 3rd Sunday in Lent.
“Yesterday I bought a T.P. to help me on [the?] underground way to a matinée - Behold the [????] v
George Dawson!
Question at the Birm. School board at the introduction of an unsectarian hymn-book. George Dawson turns over the leaves.

“Lord I ascribe it to thy grace And not to chance as others do, that I was born of Christian race and not a heathen or a Jew.”
“Lord, I Ascribe to thy grace.” Author: Issac Watts (1715) Published 18 hymnals
“Would members have any objection” he said, “if this were altered to run
“Lord I ascribe it to thy grace and not to luck, or chance’s work, that I was born of Jewish race, and not a Christian or a Turk.
I am fraid the wrath & influenced my first great teacher, as in this T.P. should be recognized nearly 40 years after this his quoted saying.
The matinée was Ray Blas. Mrs. Pat should be Mariamne – Lewis Waller might be Herod. His race has some power of inflection.
If Mrs. Pat’s voice is her own, & not worn

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 85; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 42r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: like false hair. What a fungus creature she is – not a wholesome growth for blossom & fruit – well-coloured & of the abnormal-earthly.

list.item: I speak of her as shown in Ray Blas.

p.hi: Thursday, March 3
rd

div.p: The artists dine. Shannon comes first – vengeful from a committee. He is looking & confesses to being well. His sanguines are fluent & his eyes have a transparency they have not had for very long. He immediately admires the blouses & Michael’s stronger-curl.
Then Fay comes, hurried, looking very small meeting Shannon with amity, & the Curl with the assurance it makes its mistress look years younger – “into three fingers” she intensifies.

p.hi: Dinner

div.p: Clear Soup
Cod à la Crême
Black cocks
Chocolate Jelly
Pine-chunks & Junket
Champignons Farcis
Fay has been reading Josephus’ portrait of Cleopatra. This r--aised Queen of

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 86; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 42v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Egypt lends herself to farce. She is a fruit of a putrescent civilization like the Chinese Empress. He is greatly interested in hearing about Dryden’s All For Love, in wh: Cleopatra becomes a Nell Gwynn. He specially enjoys Dryden’s fine bit of psychology where Anthony, forced again to meet the deserted Cleopatra, Ant. exclaims “God, I thank you: I formed the danger greater than it was, and now ‘tis near ‘tis lessened”
Michael & Fay get up to betting a box of chocolates to a green tie that Duse will not play little Arthur’s Tristram.
When the mushrooms come there is exhortation: “Hush! No-one is to speak to me for several moments” - & he begins to listen. No flavor is so full of itself as a mushroom’s.

Fay has been talking to an architect named Wilson who has pleased him by realizing that the Greeks & the Japs are the only two peoples who have lived for beauty & the Japs have per-sisted for centuries while the Greeks were blighted only too

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 87; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 43r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Quickly.
In the Drawing Room there is again betting that Dr. Garnett will dedicate Shakespeare, Pedagogue & Poacher to us.
Then Fay reads Verlaine’s marvelous Langueur (“Jadis et Naguère”)
I shall always hear his voice, low as an underground rillet – now & then with petuland emphasis – as it gave:
“O n'y vouloir, o n'y pouvoir mourir un peu!
Ah, tout est bu, tout est mangé - plus rien à dire.”
And again:
“L'âme seulette a mal au coeur d'un ennui dense”
And the massive first line becomes of fate, yet altogether personal, in his convinced voice -
“Je suis l'Empire à la fin de la décadence.”

Fay says this poem is that rarest thing, that had only been known in English & Italian, a Dramatic Sonnet, as Browning wrote Dramatic Lyrics. Michael grieves Browning never found the Dramatic Sonnet. Rosetti has several examples. Fay hates specially the exquite exquisite repetitions – a special charm in Verlaine - & the even more wonderful diminutive “Seulette”.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 88; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 43v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: We end the Evening by an hour with Bernhard’s Italian Florentine Drawings – specially the Leonardo Drawings & the Michael Angelo Drawings.

Fay keeps wandering nearer & nearer as Shannon & S look – then he stands over us panning into Shannon’s ear the wondrous story of how this figure is for that picture & e. Always he judges by quality of draughtsmanship or modelling – the life under the bodily forms, the life of the line.

They both agree with me the youth with Curls, & the face of the Louvre Bacchus is no Leonardo - & Fay holds that the attribution of the Pieta of Michael Angelo to Piombo
Sebastiano Del Piombo, Italian painter of High Renaissance and Mannerist Periods. is a howler. Nearly as bad is the ascription of the Casa Buonarrotti
Casa Buonarroti is a museum in Florence. The building was a property owned by (but never occupied by) the sculptor Michelangelo, which he left to his nephew, Lionardo Buonarroti. Mother & Child to Bugiardini – the supreme masterpiece of child-modelling! These out-cast Michael Angelos are of the master’s very essential might; the trouble seems to be that Bernhard seems to have <has> gone initially wrong

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 89; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 44r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: on Michael Angelo because he takes him on the side of the Windsor Drawings which, if genuine, are fluffy & un-esential in technique, & not by his salient & inapproachable work in black & white.
When the Artists hear that Benhard is coming to England simply to see us, Shannon maintains this is the excuse. He does not like Land’s End & remembers the Calais passage.

As, so deeply have I been involved with the [doom?] of our Edomite. I have not written a word of Mary’s letter from Washington Feb. 18th that undoes all the harshness of the letter that struck the last night in the old year. She writes
“Dearest Michael,

Your letter was a perfect joy – no, I can’t possibly tell you how the Doctrine & S enjoyed it, nor how we hope you have, by this time “happy feet”! [Michael had said she thought as she was buying new stockings ‘What is the use of stockings for feet that are not happy’]…Our feet are happy for we are turning East-

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 90; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 44v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: again. Logan says we must bring home something equivalent to Columbus’ cocoanuts & parrots to show that our America really exists _ the wonderful genial, tolerant, growing New World we have discovered! We shall bring home a tongueful of things to tell you at least; & may we come & tell them some evening, either the 23 or 24 of March??
For the Doctrine is stopping over just to see you two, dear Michael & Field, who mean so much more to him than you can possibly know.”
It is curious how crocusy I feel under the yellow fog has white-violety under the abortive snow-flakes. I pretend to live with the muses & not to notice Aphrodite is among them.

p.hi: Friday, March 5

div.p: I am in bed sick to misery with the cold fog. Michael ventures out to take Grace Worthington on a visit to the Palace. All the hollow time of her absence I read Anatole France’s Histoire Comique - a secondary book as all his are, with moments

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 91; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 45r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: of amazing psychology & sudden new views opening on humanity. The haunting actor-lover is well done & the little actress herself has biting traits of personality while the situations frankly due to her temperament are not fantastic. How naked & unashamed a French Writer can be in his story! It prevents one fall – the sins of stuffiness in a work of Art. The last scene of the nude acting before Love of the part that would be dressed before the world is a fresh piece of achievement.

Grace was wild with joy that Michael appeared – she was waiting arid. A plumed hat much admired in America, fresh new gloves, a whiteness of front had all been put on that Michael should not feel ashamed of her at the Palace. Fay would not let his visiters move about at first “not till they we are a little more used to each other.” Grace praised the beauty of Neville Lytton – Fay dispraised Cockerill “you must not speak against him – he is in Egypt: he may be ill” warned Michael mock-heroically then they talked of Tommy’s child-like appearance. Then Fay gave the two notes of the robin – one ordinary

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 92; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 45v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: one a divine delight of four notes. He spoke of the “sour” note of the swallow. He cannot touch birds. He babbled very unattachingly of the Dogs. They so barked he often almost turned from the door, till he remembered the Stone Cream inside.

Grace saw with happy recognition the toplady glass pot still half-heaped with little love-apples. “Still alive!” exclaimed Michael “_ah, I see, you put the top on & keep them without air, like your enemies!”
He showed the Tammy-Pendant, & - let Day hide its face! – a broach for Marie – a white bird.
Never will he see my blue bird again. Like the Bride of the Riccardi it disappears.

Then the Villain remarks he is sorry he did not do a more elaborate pendant for Tammy – a Muse riding on a Dragon with a Sphinx behind. Michael claims to see the design. The Diary is opened – there among the leaves is the great, thorny Michaelian Script. More vital that custody than the depth of drawer or chest.
The Muse can only be found ‘in small’ – it was only brought

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 93; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 46r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: up as a subject with which to sting & blandish Michael. It was designed some years ago.
March 12th. Sat.
Tommy’s poem – the Gazelles. A real poet, a fresh note – oh to wake to it!
Desire musing desires sheaf the loved one’s lap with scented cones, Fir cones! They remain fir. Good for Tommy.
this morning Henry & S formally give up “[crying?]” – we will see what mooding does. No fighting with Satan – no more giving the least heed [????].
More prayer & creeping up to God – as if there were no devil - & indeed can there be where God is.

It has been the [????] fighting that is not defence, but a sort of ineffective [assculing?] & striving. Striving is a mistake. If a spiritual-teacher I should urge absorbing – being interested-best of all last.
Of course when there is no echo Death comes. Death is the unechoing Herod [????] of this disease, & not of worms.
I ordered a pot of white violets for Painter. A pot of green leaves arrives & a [neuve?]– the White Czar!
So Painter has no [????] – merely a title. The unrealizing of things

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 94; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 46v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: -the giving one ghosts, when one wants blood – is changing one from man to inanimate
I heard the other day blood was the best nourishment for roses – a [seraphine?] of life.
The best for the renewing of the best.
March 15th
To-day Bernhard sails.
My hatred of fog is becoming cumulative – every day 24 hours more hatred.
To-day full of spring scowl. North & South East, & the causing of rooks. I go forth excited even over the [pepless?] orange & the first English strawberry.
I buy Devonshire Cream & brown, fresh eggs. Heaven sends me down 2 bunches of grapes by a [????] white & blue with which to crown my Loved.
I keep walking in & out. The River from the garden is silver-gilded, in a dusky grove.
We are reading Jane Harrison’s Prolegomana. And as one approaches the deeper mysteries of one’s own Christian faith, one gives thanks

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 95; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 47r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: That it is late, that it says Yea, & that its mysteries are spiritual.
On an aspic found gliding towards the seer.
Who art thou, aspic of the dazzled eyes,
And swaying as a drunkard from his drink?
Seaward then glidest, in the sea to sink,
a sacred alien, a sacrifice.
Who hath devoted thee? What hast thou done?
that wound is as a [jewel?] ‘mid thy scales;
thy forked tongue still tenderly assails.
As some amazing honour thou hadst won,
As thou went stricken by too vest adorn,
and to the gods must recommend my plight,
thou foqmest through the sand. Back to a tomb
I follow thy fresh steps. Ah, there in sight
the golden spindle that devised thy wound,
and Cleopatra marvelously swooned.
Tuesday March 15th (Bernhard sails) 1904.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 96; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 47v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Saturday March 19th

A rain as of April has fallen – Hennie’s heart is broken to Herod. We work together; Bernhard is on the high seas, [????] [????] is still reading his sonnet & the clothes of spring have been arriving post on post. I am happy after an arid, desperate week.
One afternoon I recall.

It is Wednesday, &, as one abandoned of hope I am curled up on the bed-room sofa, reading Jane Harrison’s Prolegomena of Ethics <Greek Religion>. A bee hit & the gods are tossed over as nine-pins, while I wrestle into my Albrect Dürer gown.
The talk is chiefly of Don Giovanni – but in truth we meet to wail.

With Painter it is a season of absolute barrenness – he is lying low. I tell him I shall say to Bernhard “there is not a sign of him” left, “[ever?] a sign ”he murmurs,” when Bern-hard is by. I am in eclipse.”
I amuse him from a heart, dropping like a stalactite-cave.
O child of Helène, Cornelia, Pia, Decclata – what place is there for you in this world?
I tell him [????] is come to say good-bye before starting for Italy. No, he is only come to say it is the only day this week he can come. the minutiae

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 97; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 48r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: The microbes of clothingness are eating him up. I cannot write of him. I should not mind unhappiness or hardship for him – I cannot watch him fall into disuetude.
I have sent him [mignonette?] & forget-me-nots & “image & superscription”, & I have have written comfortable words…
But this kettle of fish, with the live eels leaping about in their agony, is too much for me.
One or two friends, his peers, a little fame, consciousness of “a welling up” & the threat of poverty withdrawn – we so change him - my Publisher, who must roam the earth a Poet!

Yes, there is strangeness about Fay – he seems blank as an unsown plough-field; & yet there is bustle about him of endless en-gagements & fritter…But the mystery! He is not in the world – in society – philanthropy business…With what Keres has he then engagements? He says he has been reading interesting books & when we question he binds his brow with his hands & recalls nothing, with a willowy, ghost-like laugh.
He really warns Michaels against writing a play on Don Juan

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 98; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 48v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: when she shall have heard the story from him – “It would not suit her – it is strictly copyright”. Then as if playing a last card he tells all the mad rigamorole of the libretto – chuckling over its formal bits of eighteenth century “business” & humour – sliding lissome eyes down the discreet innuendo, or unabashed follies of the plot & ending on a note of veritable awe at the grip of the Stone Hand.

He sees a play – I do not – Opera & Satire seem to me to exhaust the story. I suggest “Does he mean a moral play in a few scenes, like Masterhick’s Beatrice, in wh: the first unrepented sin of a man becomes his eventual doom & death warrant?” No, he would make a play of manners, like Measure for Measure!
Michael tells his the story of little [Horrie?], who questioned her father one Sat. night “Dada, [have?] you

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 99; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 49r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: got the chocolate for me?” & when forgetfulness was confessed by Dada, sent remarked “Then you’d better go for it at once, before you forget again” – adding when he reached the door “I have noticed you don’t think so much of your Baby lately” of course he flew for the chocolate with such perfect womanhood ordering & pleading from the tiny bed. Fay was enchanted.

Then wicked Michael told of Dara L.’s remark, after she had praised Shannon’s beauty his sweet mouth (“He hasn’t got one at all” interpolates Fay) & turned to Fay’s own portrait “He is exactly like a Mr. Wright, who taught me drawing 30 years ago, & very like a clergyman I used to know.”
At the end Michael, pointing to her velvet stomacher, asks “Do you know what this demands?”
“No – ”
“A Cochon d’Or” ___ & he flies.
“Mind you remember M to tell Shannon of the drawing master of 30 years ago.” So Michael harasses the flight. “Let me see – Wright that’s the name!” “Yes – 30 years ago!”--- & he is gone.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 100; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 49v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Saturday - March 19th

After sultry days of inner sand & East-wind outside a ripple of life – Herod is alive – There is fire in the heart & <a>long the road & bridges of the brain. All the scenes, all the situations are ductile again – one can view them from their source, & follow their interaction.

Then tonight comes a letter from Fay – greatly thanking Michael for flowers & sonnet “Mr. Wright that is Mr All-Right thanks you greatly - & likes it (the sonnet) very much as a poem – in fact as much as a likeness”
“only the Ear is bright” might lead to immediate recognition in the part of the public (He always seems to see his sonnets printed!)
“Mr Wright’s friend (Ireland’s only hope) is also appreciative though he read out the title of the piece as “Image & Superstition”
Then comes the usual plaint “I

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 101; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 50r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: am writing in a dazed condition, having spent the morning in letters of evasion & excuse” – to what Keres?
“Small tiresome events have been so thick of late that I think my star just now is “with the Russians’.”

Tommy has had a two-column Review in the Times Supplement – very welcoming, not ungenially laden with ‘blame, as most reviews are now.’ We have sent it to Rome, marking the judgement “He lives too much with painters.”

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 102; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 50v; Andrew Walt.

div.p: [E.C]
March 23rd Wednesday.

It is a now afternoon, & we are expecting Bernhard
The women often added an “h” to Bernard Berenson’s name. this evening. The rooms are full of lilies, & keenly red roses, & growing purple crocuses & the ice crevice - white azalias. Outside the East & north discourse of futility & disillusion, while the river wells up into wavelets that press turbulently. Before me is the wonder at mortality & Eros in their possible fusion. I feel such a congeries of dust, that I cannot conceive of myself as in relation with the immortal God of fire & life. I am faded with springtide & with the tide of time. I feel as dust. And he too - the beloved - is a little thing of dust & of the years that pass; yet there is a god between us, & all are atoms of dust, our moments of time, do not discourage the immortal.

On Sunday little Dodge, who came to hear Tommy’s Gazelles
A poem written by Thomas Sturge Moore (1870-1944). He served as Bradley’s and Cooper’s literary executor. read, told us that B.
Bernard Berenson. was not expected. On Monday Michael going to Miss Toplady’s
A small London antique shop. Named after an elderly tenant, but run by Logan Smith, the brother of Mary Smith. heard B. was not expected & broke into torrent of wrath...Then in stepped Logan
Logan Pearsall Smith (1865-1946). Essayist and Critic, perhaps most well-known for his autobiography. & announced “Well, they are here, as large as life” - “Is B. come too” - “Yes - I can’t think what for. He is only coming for two days.” My beloved hoped to tell me the birthday of my love had come - but just before her arrival a telegram came from Mary. “Wednesday, with so much pleasure.”

Yesterday, Michael went to the palace to enlighten Fay’s
Charles de Sousy Ricketts (1866-1931). Charles Ricketts was an English Artist, Illustrator, Author and Printer. Eclipse, bearing a box of lustrous purples crocuses - I never saw such quarry; they looked like shining young stags in a heap. Who else would sickle crocuses thus in their sleek abundance...And Fay had gone, his fellow did not know where - thought to Richmond. He had not turned up to lunch. It made us most down-hearted & anxious last night, & lay

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 104; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, 51v; Andrew Walt.

div.p:
heavy on going to sleep. However as we have heard nothing & Shannon
Charles Haslewood Shannon (1863-1937). English Artist. Partner of Ricketts. thought he had come here we conclude all is well. Dear Fay - for him to disappear even for a few hours is like a mistake of the sun or stars. Mary
Mary Berenson, nee Mary Smith (1864-1945). Art Historian, and was married to Bernard Berenson. & B. are to go to tea at the palace tomorrow.
I must go & dress - the rooms await Eros; the congeries of dust is still unadorned for the visitation.

When we come down dressed, the river was <is> silver, grown into a strength, silver on the march & on [‘][war?] [footing?][‘]. I never have seen such an attractive flood.It is obscured all too soon - the lilies swept on long stems the frizzled radiance of their flowering over <in front of> the flood. It was marvellous. A voice at the door! “No - it is not Bernhard. - Some-one bearing a parcel” - the door opens...but the voice was his! He comes alone. Mary has had a delayed

div.p: [E.C]

attack of sea-sickness. We are very sorry - her jollity would have transfused blood into the meeting. From the first I feel he is God-forsaken - a little desecrated shrine. There is no God to meet. My heavy premonition is tragically justified. At dinner he burst out into silly blasphemies, Michael bravely stems while Lillias
Either Logan Smith or Lilias Trotter. Lilias Trotter (1853-1928), was an English artist and a Protestant Missionary to Algeria. She was rewarded with high praise from John Ruskin for her art before she became a missionary. boils behind me. Nothing makes me more angry than this profane attacking <of religion> in general talk at table - it ought to be impossible - bad form. Of course one forgets nightly there are servants in the room when the thousand things of converse flash & more: but there is one thing that should never be treated with contempt in their presences, because they are bound to be silent - that is religion. This noble manners to humanity to remember this. All Bernhard says is of at the kind that comes near to braying. “That cut-dash purse, that unspeakable cad - the chosen of God - your Psalmist David” - is a wild specimen. By the way he speaks of Herod as another David - another chosen of God - When we try to turn the subject

div.p: [E.C]
of the Bible & introduce Josephus.

Bernhard is an American - convinced, but not (as Michael wittily puts it) infectious. He has with a certain wisdom, that has overdeveloped into infatuation, tried to get the best out of the men he has met - the gigantic pork - butchers & cold-storers & etc till they have become “The eponymous heroes” of America - indeed, they have become America. It is silly as it would be to call our indispensable Cook Paragon.

He never wearied of their financial marshalling of their facts - he could have listened for months & years. There was friendships too among them - Achilles & Patroclus could have been seen in the pork-butcheries.
There is no rippling of conversation - only a dull current - & Bernhard looks dusky,like a golden lad who, like a chimney-sweeper, has is come to dust where is the light of him?
He is only ‘life-enhancing’ on the

div.p:
subject of Rickett’s
Charles de Sousy Ricketts (1866-1931). Charles Ricketts was an English Artist, Illustrator, Author and Printer. art. He realizes that Ricketts, like all real artists, has themes in the forces that condition his art - that he is illuminated to treat in the great manner the pressure & recoil of human bodies, with the <a> resulting rhythm - the Samaritan, the Centaur, the Entombment are all variations on the great laws of repose pressure & resistance. And being therefore elemental in theme, they are important as a drawings by Leonardo are important. Bernhard seems to be desirous of attaching Fay; I cannot help suspecting in this swell of appreciation the meshes of a drag-net. He is the man who counts as a spiritual force on this side the channel.

B. seems a gorged little thing - no charming words about the roses, the lilies, the dainty cates that almost cost us ruin on a month of the year. No heart-felt word on health or happiness! Yet nothing inimical - only a friendlessness of soul. At dinner he

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 108; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, 53v; Andrew Walt.

div.p: says he does not come to eat, but to talk - “I would go anywhere to talk” & I feel how futile to say so. There can be no talk after; & there is not. “I am giving you an American evening” he sighs out, as if dissatisfied. Just for a short space, when left alone, I tell him of my pleasure in his chapter & notes, on Leonardo, & my appreciation of the more restive & athletic style of the Micheal Angelo. And I tell him of touches I have given to his most enticing & personal sentences. We are warmer a moment - a gulf-stream just fringes our apartness - no more. Even then he says with dusky petulance “You know, Field, I am a great person in America.”

I cry when he is gone. If it is tragic for a God to take on human limits - it is abjectly painful for a man to keep his poor limits & not take on some deity. He goes through the door a small, trim man; & therefore full of disappointment to himself & to others. He is dust - he is trivial. I have seen him once too often.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 109, Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 54r, Wendy Walter

div.p: March 24th.

He has lost all power of mood. All atmosphere is withdrawn. One would suffocate if one entered into his soul as a dog suffocates in a lethal chamber. His eyes are worse than blind- They are there, not perceiving. He has drunk of the sweetness of adulation, of the bitterness of spite; for inspiration he believes the pork-butchers are making the world go. Poor little Bernhard! God has to bear all this from us; but this Easter we will try to offer Him Souls, as fresh & welcomed as a bit of [????]
surf [????] pris lark!
Palm Sunday
March 27th

We have provided our palm [????] aforehand. We have put them away, for they stink. But I feel soft & open toward the world where these feasts are kept- I read hymns-hymns that bring before me the brows -the seas of the dead- I read Herrick
Herrick: Robert Herrick, 1591-1674. English lyric poet and cleric.‘O “Sweet Spirit Comfort me”
O-Sweet Spirit Comforter: a phrase from Robert Herrick’s poem, “Litany to the Holy Spirit”. there is fog outside, & even the birds forget to cry out.
Day of sweet blessedness & triumph-I bless it still with its <[????]> [????]& [????] hearts.
Yesterday I visited Mary lying in dazzling white silk & face as dazzling,

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 110, Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 54v, Wendy Walter

div.p: After 24 hours (delayed) sea-sickness. Ricketts was going to call on her, yesterday afternoon.

Janet and I assist at Yeats
Yeats: William Butler Yeats (1865-1939). A well-known Irish poet. play “The King’s Threshold.” To my surprise the lovely, clear verse comes
flowing up come in the back rows of the dress-circle.
Only Yeats, I think, could have made that scene of the poet lying starving on the steps, not ridiculous
the cumulative force of the speech <poet> is very strong. The lover’s kiss will be more fervent & more golden for his resistance, in ages to come-but there should not be a petty triumph at the end.
He should starve & die in his misery- the king perhaps visit him a little shuddering, <after death> & with orders for a great funeral.

There is sufficient force in “the Defense of Poetry
A Defence of Poetry" is an essay by the English poet, Percy Bysshe Shelley, written in 1821 and
published posthumously in 1840. for one to be sure of the issue-

Helen Fry
Helen Coombe Fry: wife of Roger Fry, friend of Yeats., magnificent, was there moving about —on another plane. Bernhard
Bernhard: Bernard Berenson, 1865-1959. An American art historian and friend of Bradley/Cooper. was there —a dusk & dusty fly. Old Archer crossed me, a [????] of other years.
I return & read to my Beloved with something of the sustained cadence I have [????] the whole
play.
The other two plays are unclassed.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 111, Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 55r, Wendy Walter

div.p: Monday, March 28th

But this is the gay Fairy man of years ago! He knows I wanted him “to run down the Lamb,” & to discuss the Irish plays. Mary is like the earth or the sea, -very comely, a little crude. Bernhard was very polite at the Palace
Palace: A nickname for the Ricketts/Shannon home: Lansdowne House, Holland Park; but he is christened “Wopsie-Topsie;” & one feels that the apparition of 94
Apparition of 94: Possibly referring to Encke's Comet Apparition of 1894-1895. has been caught.

Yeat’s play is clean & very Greek - the poet, of course, should have died & the people of the court should have shown a great coldness to the king. After his death <(Yeat’s chief actor)>3 Fay’s acting impressed Painter.
Painter: nickname for Charles Shannon. Tommy
Thomas Sturge Moore (1870-1944). has been rebuked in a letter for dealing as he has with so great a gentleman as Don Juan.
The mood of trouble has passed from Painter & the frolic of a breeze is round him, as a halo.

p.hi: Wednesday in Holy Week

div.p:
From a letter to Amy7
Amy: Katherine Bradley’s niece.

“And now [????] for I want some fun. I am feeling very happy in my spirit, & the hail and the thunder can’t hurt me. Paragon
Paragon: Katherine Bradley and Edith Cooper’s home looks so sweet. It is decked with pots of Azalea, & the growing, living flowers bring the Blessed near. Then my Painter

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 112, Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 55v, Wendy Walter

div.p: [????] very wonderful on Monday, & this morning I have the picture of him ringed – matter of triumph to any woman to have ringed that perfect hand— more to have been poet to those

grave, Southern eyes. Henry
Henry: Katherine Bradley’s nickname for Edith Cooper. says with [????] his eyes in their gravity are as sunless olive-groves.
and now no more. I cannot write at all these great Feast times — but do “00” write, & give my
love & blessing to [????], & let us hear of the parlours & Alice.”

Painter’s visit is delicious- It has greatly enlivened him to dish ‘the Lamb’ with much mint sauce. I cannot help admiring the touch of crisp ridicule in his pose toward his rival. The way in wh: he says he was getting on beautifully with Mrs. Mary when ‘Wopsy’
Wopsy: nickname for Bernard Berenson. came in from the play is a masterpiece
of sleight-of-wit.

He gives a sportive & adulterous airiness of suggestion that is mirth-provoking. Yet his real gravity of judgment, for when he judges he is serious as Minos
Minos: The mythical King of Crete who lived over the labyrinth and the Minotaur., is shown in his phrase, ‘Mary has diminished Bernhard — this is

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 113, Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 56r, Wendy Walter

div.p: greatly observed, because Mary impresses him as so large & buoyant in herself. But a grea< large> sea-shore of wind & salt & sun does not always cultivate our fineness or the reaches of our sympathies. Logan he is interested in — he is like the liftmen, who died because Michael did not recognize he was a sonneteer.

B. came to the Palace in a ‘topper’ — this was offensive: he put it down on a satinwood table, under flowers specially arranged to irritate him, — this was more offensive. He was questioned on America, so as to give the replies he didn’t want to; then was taken round, & made the artists richer by assuring them a drawing they held in question was a real Andrea del Sarto
Andrea del Sarto: (1486-1530) Italian Renaissance painter..

Fay
Fay: nickname for Charles Ricketts. finds him elaborate & in mind, rather “sleepy.” He diag-nosed him as shrewd rather than intelligent — slow in his judgment. But of course we all know the real Bernhard is far away, not in America but in a long cloud-land journey.
As soon as Fay comes into the

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 114, Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 56v, Wendy Walter

div.p: grot he exp <exclaims> “What a charming sofa you have there” he quite adores the lacquered
little piece of 1820-30. He is obliged to agree with me that every curve is false— yet he is charmed
all the same he is amused— it is fun. And— he loves to see Michael on it supporting her arm,
like a [????] lady. The skirt training, the fantastic curves round her. He feels
her choice in the rogue of a couch; & its hump & flamboyancy attract him magnetically.
We sit in the grot round our ‘Ninon’. How merry we are! Decidedly ‘lamb & mint sauce’ make the
Painter’s heart gay

Fay remarked that Yeat’s second line in ‘On The King’s Threshold’
On the Kings Threshold: A W.B. Yeats play. about the two kinds of music
‘one that is like a man & one that is like a woman’ made him quite uncomfortable. There are aesthetic mistakes that strike one as improper –& one glances at the ladies.
Bernhard, coming back from Yeats’ play, after some [????]

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 115, Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 57r, Wendy Walter

div.p: & hedging, admitted he felt he had been present at the birth of a new something new.
Fay noted the Greek directness of Yeats. I attribute it to his having drawn, like the Greek Dramatists his subject from [????] sources – where narrative is direct.

We show Fay le jeunesse de Balzac
Le Jeune Balzac: Work of Honoré de Balzac when he was young. — the frank portrait of his bursting youth. Balzac Fay almost hates, except his Contes Drolatiques.
Contes Drolatiques: A collection of Balzac’s off-color stories. In these he finds a quintessence stronger in its imaginative force than Cervantes
Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra (1547-1616) Spanish writer of Don Quixote. or Rabelais
François Rabelais was a French Renaissance writer, best known for his fantasy, satire, the grotesque, bawdy jokes and songs. is [????]. It is a new creation in a sphere where there is so little novelty.
Fay agrees that the actor Fay, who directs the Irish Theatre is one of the best alive, in spite
of amateur-training. Fay shrinks from writing to Yeats lest he should call — his presence is disquieting — there is something paralytic about it. And it is so tiresome to hear him talk about
“po-etry” & wave his hands round it.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 116; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 57v; Ayah Hamed Falatah

div.p: Good Friday -

A dazzling day - almost it glitters as on the classic- good Friday morning when [????] from my hoop - & felt in the air endless [bun?], the sky & ecstasy. It is a pure spring day, & even the first little catastrophe in [????] cannot damp it.
Talk of swallows - when the first little flotella of boats lies on the surface of the Thames then to our waterside there is spring.

We have spent the day very simply. We read of Christ parting with his mother, & the "it is finished" &, after breakfast, Henry asked for my two Good Friday sonnets. We have been busy with a scene of Mariamne - the <her> last.

And I have written four lines of the second sonnet on Painter’s
Painter: nickname for Charles Shannon picture.
But what is the Beloved to behold more than another? He is pure as substances that grain on grain endure, as amber gris eternal in its gold.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 117; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 58r; Ayah Hamed Falatah

div.p: Easter Day.
We give each other, not eggs,- fine cigarettes & liquid ambergris.
We wake in the dream-bed room there are green-bay leaves on Father's altar, & we turn to look at the portraits of the parents.

We speak much of the ideal qualities in Father, how Henry’s genius is from him - & I drop into recollection of the [????] family experienced - & the congregation of the Church of the Savior, & all who knew reverenced her that Emma Bradley
Emma Bradley: Emma is Katharine's sister and Edith's mother. should marry one so unworthy of her. Well, he was worthy of in heart, & infinitely finer in endowment. He had brain: Henry's brain, & a conscientiousness of unused power. He made himself absurd to our stupid ears by declaring he could astonish us in preaching, or writing. Alas, no: with us the eloquence, the tongue - as the Euphrates in its abundance - he could not speak; he could fashion.

Mother - the very bloom & flower of religion - seemed no fitting bride for the old-fashioned countryman with his traditional faith & manners. Once [????] in aglow over some <evidence> trait of acumen in Edith - said "But with a a mother like Emma, the Bradley’s VP."
“But Emma [????] [????]" was

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 118; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 58v; Ayah Hamed Falatah

div.p:
The portrait of Fay
Fay: nickname for Charles Ricketts. is a wonderful thing. It is Pan - the eyes know the [????] secrets of the universe so intimately, they caress & fondle them - are lazy with them, <are> amused.

and the lips close as if at rest from a shout, or a [????] - some of the startling sounds that make us aware of secrets or create them in our blood. There is a touch that is grim in the soft undulance- something disconcerting & of the power of austerity in the midst of suppleness. that month is closed, because the god is under a cavern in the efficiency of his contemplation. He dents his cheek with one finger & gathers up his jaw in a hand that supports the world as easily as Atlas’ neck.

One feels the ears must crenulate into leaves - so much the hearing will be extraordinary, as in the alleys of a forest - and even the month prepares one for the goat's beard - the malice of it is a little heady, there is the touch of roughness, that is solitary, in its civil, star-

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 119; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 59r; Ayah Hamed Falatah

div.p: charmed quiet.

One could beat him with squills so heartily, if opposed to one - & then ruin a g away as if a phantom made you <one> cold. Yet he is too balanced to be tragic- he sits in his cave & thinks, not of catastrophes but of consolations, till his eyes grown gentle & have entertainment in them.

Pan - with complexion like the air in sensitiveness of life- Pan who can be boisterous & <can be> evocative as an upland pipe - always mysterious, on watch, not to be resisted. Pan who a poet has ringed.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 120; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 59v; Ayah Hamed Falatah

div.p: Easter-Day continued
the deserved retort.

We speak of emotion - of our own fitness for each other. Without me Henry says, you would have been no poet.” "yes," - Longfellow.” Henry says emotion grows could through contact with the air: emotion must be from the bubbling cauldrons within He says how he & Fay have cleaned my genius - that Fay has cleaned it, as with emery powder.

I am able to spring out of bed, & read “Christ the Lord is risen to-day” from the old hymn-book. Henry repeats "Christ is [????]" & I read "Christ on passover is sacrificed for us, therefore let us reap the feast.
Now I commit Henry to Heaven's care in the perilous hour of her communion with the dead.
I should not like to meet her that way, nor do I believe the attempt would prosper; side by side - the [chink?] of two oboli- & one boat - that is my prayer for us.
The first taste of the real life together - the wonder in each other’s eyes - my Easter prayer.
We have bag- bag triumphant over each altar - Victory!

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 121; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 60r; Ayah Hamed Falatah

div.p: -and on Easter even I raved across to fetch black poplar from the other side.
-black poplar for the mother.
She has received it & I am blessed.
The growing crocus is in the boxes, <in> & <[????] the> little [couch?] of rest.
The crocus & the poppy are both flowers I could have migrated into, & the impatient poppy most of all.
There is nothing inhuman in this Easter day of spring-gale & sunshine.
We hear the rooks in their [nookiness?] as they caw, life is so excellent: we give thanks for life; & for redeemed life- life made holy in its very blood- we give thanks.
“What is thy Beloved more than another Beloved”

But what is thy Beloved to behold more than another? - He is pure as substances that grain on grain endure as ambergris eternal in its gold. More wonderful & in aloofness bold. His looking faith, more sensuously sure than Pan's when from great caverns that [????]
He looks abroad with all his flocks to fold. More than another he is beautiful, nor is there any balm that gathereth
His sweetness up, or flower that you can pull:
From his own ecstasy he [????]
Even as a camel feeding on myrrh - trees.
Blows from his nostrils aromatic wreath
Finished Easter Even

div.p: April 7th
There was a Spanish heat-wave yesterday. For a few hours Loved & I walked to & fro in the sunshine. To-day extreme scowl & flutter of wind: [H?] curled up by the fire.

I have sent a chocolate Easter Fish for little dolly (the blind woman's child of the Norfolk family.) Ms. [Sceulaud?] writes her thanks for Dolly's nice fish. ''I wish you could have seen her. O my [pensent?]. She clasped her little hands danced jumped about when that come & my word we were as pleased as the child. I had to take her to Grandfather. He laugh till the water ran down his face.''
Infinite jest of the chocolate fish! We have brought tears of mirth to an old man's eyes – & [????] [????] down with laughter!
A child at the zoo said '' Tiger, look at me''. At last she threw into the den her own infinitely precious Easter egg.
The tiger pushed out a paw – no egg, but a shriek that waved its way even to the monkey-house.

Frances Power Cobbe
Frances Power Cobbe (4 December 1822 – 5 April 1904) was an Irish writer, social reformer, anti-vivisection activist, and leading women's suffrage campaigner. died on Tuesday April 5th. A very brave, a very gallant woman. But for the sake of the most

XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 61r; Samah Damanhoori

div.p: precious things of the spirit for the sake of the Saveur of the vines, and the fragrant substances

of earth- one must make protest against her. First of all- bone as ever woman is the man's helpmate- the hated man <(as man)> & boasted that she had not been desired of him or desiring. She did not produce flower or fruit after her kind.
May she energise in Mars somewhere!
-perhaps - there among the canals she will do less harm!
Extract from letter to Amy.

-''You have never made the tears roll down Grandfather's face! Our reward has been a black bird's nest with four blue, spotted eggs. Our re-turn eggs: & clear sweet throated Dickie feeling suddenly choky in his singing - for his beautifully-built cottage those, & four mysterious little music - books all gone.”
April 9th

The languor, the melancholy of the spring -my mind is an almanac. Full of the probabilities of low tides. I calculate every morning the possible extent of my tenure- How long this machine will be to me- Life as it might be, seems so attractive in age, & the drinking of the air so sweet! It is the season of the spring that searches & gripes!
In the autumn I feel contemporaneous- like a nice, ripe plum. In the spring- like a goose-berry flower, dropping < turning off>.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 124; Vol.
XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 61v; Samah Damanhoori
April 8

div.p: Such primroses from Janet Dodge!
I have written:

A fresh & immediate note of thanks for the primroses, dear Janet. Among the difficult Arts of Beautiful Living the Art of gathering & presenting primroses is scarcely ever learnt. Janet is perfect in it. One usually receives primroses with a sense of nervous prostration, such as a picture-gallery produces; & with an inarticulate hatred for the giver. But I lift out of an orderly box little separate nosegays, their tender stems, that always make me think of the feet of arab girls that have the heels & nails flushed with henna, are ready to be dipped in water. I bring out the great ivory lead bowl, I set the primroses' feet to shine under its deep bath; & there are the primroses in their orient yellow, giving out their languid perfume. – sweet girls, but not to me of the west.
I bless Janet & so will Michael when she returns from town.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 125; Vol.
XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 62r; Samah Damanhoori

div.p: April 13th
April is with us – the river sucks like a young babe.
White rooted violets are come to us- Violets that look their scent. We hear of the Manner Garden a sheet of violets crossed off daffodils.

I frolic with the small leaves. I write to [????] who wanted us to visit her [Rugcite?] Cottage on Saturday. '''Why do widows always spoil one's happiness?'' as the widow's Son remarked, licking the oil from his lips, when restored to life by Elijah.''

On the priory Park from [Greg's?] letter. ''this morning Babs & I paced slowly & reverently as if in church over the priory ridge- the old monks paced there of old-feeling the same silence – the same music too- the heavenly choir of larks vying with each other in their sweet sopranos- a lowing cow in the distance chanting the amens in bass, a chanticleer further off, still with a contralto solo- trying to put out the larks. At our feet little, wild strawberries in blossom, & small wood violets. I have taught Babs not to pick wild flowers &s''
Monday, April 18th
Henry has been ill since Friday with a strange, & most disquieting numbness

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 126; Vol.
XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 62v; Samah Damanhoori

div.p: in her lower limbs. On Saturday, the Doctor. “The thing is superficial, but mysterious, & it creeps. It is like a growing tide. Panic seizes me, not in the superficies; Henry trembles.

On Sunday Henry is in bed all day. the widow & Tommy- these adverse souls- encounter at supper. What is that “Lilac bass” the widow asks of the ring? ''And what is the loose emerald for?'' to look bright and to run about'' – retorts Tommy tartly.

The widow reports Tommy ''quite satisfied'' but there is more than quite satisfied in the deeply- beaming face. He does not speak of Marie she is present as fresh verdure to his soul- a <fresh> gentle human element discernible already in his ways and words, especially the way he flaps his soul.
He is soundly the same to us
Of Monday April 18th
Painter comes in response to command. I am still in tumult of anxiety - concerning Henry.
Painter speaks of the 1st act of Sabbatai.
He has liked the beginning of act I- the scene with the Spirit.
I read to him 2 sonnets- averring that one of them is addressed to Tommy. He vows he will punish that sonnet. Afterwards he remarks in reference to a fine simile- Tommy is like a camel.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 127; Vol.
XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 63r; Samah Damanhoori

div.p: It is now Wednesday- my dear one is growing better.
''We welcome each rebuff
That turns the smoothness rough.'' & even a corn that dances is [hailed?].
Yes, Henry is better & the tips of everything exquisite: the garden wall-flowers, grape-hyacinths, fritillaries, auriculas.
[P?] Newman on May Day (Sunday) May Day. & Melton-men 1904
Morning
Never hastening Paragon greeted the May with such pride. The air of the garden is sweet with gilly- flowers. There are fritillaries, red & white daisies, pansies, forget-me-nots & tulips on the beds.
there is Henry …
the wide, fragrant leaves lie in the sun, & that is how I feel.

I have written little in this fortnight Henry has been busy fighting the Devil at his nerve-ends. I have been helping. His illness is, I believe, for the strengthening of our wills. &, if we have grace to use if so, will infinitely enrich us.
Last Friday Painter dined with us.
He came lagged, & angry; & gradually recovered & grew young.
He was full of enthusiasm over

div.p: Congrieve’s play. The Way of the World. Mr. Wright full of force & blood-power.

p.hi: Illness & Convalescence

div.p:
On Thursday April 14th I went to the Manor House
Hotel in London & had delight with Jan
Janet Ross, English historian and biographer & Amy
Amy Levy, queer Jewish poet and friend to Bradley and Cooper in their sheets of double-daffodils in the Knarled old garden - now a town garden, stranded among trams & rail-lines, with all its gold flowers, its fruit-buds, its bowls of Persian-lilac trees, dusk with coming clusters - its glowing new gravel, with worth £15.

The return journey was hot, as if lined with thunder & Michael & I were sundered at Kew Bridge. She assisted an old lady in a wedding garment of gray satin on to the platform - Puff! The train glided off & I saw a face like a wind-tossed rose, under the black hat with its plumes of white & matching them the reef of the dear white teeth. However we were soon re-united - but we did not like the severance;

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 129; Vol XVIII, Add MS 267893, fol. 64r, Mia Vodanovich

div.p: it had suffering for us.

all day I had had numb feet - I had passed a pumice-stone over the soles the night before to make them whiter (o foolish!) & at night I was over-heated. Next day the numbness grew - It was like the Shroud in Rossetti’s King’s Tragedy
Historical ballad about King James I of Scotland by Dante Gabriel Rossetti, brother to poet Christina Rossetti - from ankles it rose to knees, then to loins. In panic I sent on Sat. for the Doctor, & breathed again when I heard that the anaesthesia would not affect the heart (on Monday I had been for a too long day in Town, & standing in Sloane Square banished from the Tube of the fatal air & unable to settle a way home I had felt the remoteness of collapse). The dismal man said my case was “very unusual” - nice comfort for the stricken Michael.

I felt like a cold dead body from the waist - the rest of me like a disembodied Spirit held by the leg to its corpse. The weather was lovely spring-tide - sun sprang out of the trees & behold there were rays & sparkles that were living leaves. The softness, that is the circumstance of growth, ruled the temper of the hours & time.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 130; Vol XVIII, Add MS 267893, fol. 64v, Mia Vodanovich

div.p: My beloved gathered round me tulips blowing forth like roses. Amy brought me the very red rose of June.
I had an excited sense of panic - continually, like a general on the field I had to give responsible orders to my unfeeling limbs.

Bed after three days seemed to do no good - only when I first got up did the gamut queerness of my state make me weep at first. The fatigue of that general ship! Should I always be at the point of battle? Should I never let the will act unconscious? I could make my unfeeling feet dance - but the dance was to me that of winter thistle-down.

Cheer quickly came back - were not the windows rimmed with white fritillarias in front of a mist of grape hyacinths? Did not the river look bright as a snake in his new skin? Amy came & we had two or three happy sisterly meetings. Fay
Charles Ricketts came & brought snow-flakes. Sir George Douglas
George Brisbane Scott Douglas, Scottish writer and poet & Tommy
Thomas Sturge Moore, English poet, author, and artist conversed with Michael below & I heard their

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 131; Vol XVIII, Add MS 267893, fol 65r, Mia Vodanovich

div.p: histories. On Friday Feb April 21st Fay spent six hours with us. He came chafed - but handsome, every inch of moulding caressed by the breezy rain, a start of life in every end of hair.
We laughed & let him rage.

“I want to say very nice things” he protested “& soon he was good & entertained us on Congreve’s Way of the World
A comedic play about lovers Mirabell and Millamant dodging various obstacles in the way of their marriage - Unfortunately my memory could bear no tax at all - The delightful things he said are in the bridge-less limbo.

And he was long discoursing on Anatole France’s Mannequin d’osier
Novel by Anatole France, translating to English as The Wicker Mannequin - on its infinite civilization. He finds the characters touched with an infinite conception of temperament. These qualities make him read Anatole - not as a great writer, but as a finely modern one. The moment when M. Bergeret lifts his hat to Mme. Grimace is a mile-stone of progress.

Fay is for prescribing Shakespeare’s comedies to us in place of the Bible. That is primitive in style - the Comedies full of the lightness & ease of culture. His tongue seemed to dance as he talked of Love’s Labour Lost - even of The Two Gentlemen.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 132; Vol XVIII, Add MS 267893, fol 65v, Mia Vodanovich

div.p: The painter, who came like a naughty boy, left (having lost one late train) restored to [Panship?] - auriculas & great white-shouldered fritillarias in his hand.

Amy Bell
Possibly Cooper’s sister Amy, by her married name (Waterloo) came next day - a pleasant visit. Amy amplifies detail till the air is soft with what would be hard fact with a lesser woman. And on Sunday Louie Ellis
Louis Ellis, Welshman who later relocated to Australia with his family & Ysonde came early, carrying from town, for my sake, a great Longiflorum Lily.

I set it against the fritillarias & the river-grain. It makes a tapistry Morris
William Morris, English poet and textile designer could not have woven. Henry Havelock Ellis sends word that there is no peril in my state - it is frequent with brain-workers & will go. Such encouragement!
This last week Amy has been again; Shannon has been expected & failed as usual. My Love has been to town & heard Leigh read the great scene in Othello with vibrant passion centred profoundly.

We read the Bedchamber Scene in Herod
A play written by Michael Field, about the oppressive king of the Bible, after reading the Othello

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 133; Vol XVIII, Add MS 267893, fol 66r, Mia Vodanovich

div.p: Scene - it actually remained [bonneted?] by <in> the presence of its great challenger! It is as it were, of different nationality, but of the same humanity.

On Sunday, at breakfast, I said to Michael “Our passion has a tendency to walk the ground with burning feet; it rarely takes wings & flies.” This was well said of our later work - but with Herod there is more flight in this nervous Arab’s passion.

So Dr. Dot came on Friday - she too thinks my ill is transitory - & indeed it is much less of a weight in my being - use & improvement both assist me. And the dismal doctor has at last vouchsafed to say that the cases of anaesthesia he has personally known were due to Influenza. So all our panic might have been reduced to this suggestion, wh: the “hollows” in my head seem to justify.

Today - Sunday - is May Day & we are expecting Tommy & his bridg bride Marie. The meeting must be momentous, because such people are involved in its issue. Sturge Moore, Michael & Field & the Artists! How glad we shall be if she can become our friend.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 134; Vol XVIII, Add MS 267893, fol 66v, Mia Vodanovich

div.p: She accepted our invitation with “Yours respectfully”. Poor Marie! She is not of our country - therefore doubly a guest.
Such May Day!

The clusters on the wisteria en-groupe. Full of buds & bells is our little garden. The kind Oxford widow has sent me wild-flowers for the festival - the yellow wild tup tulip of Oxfordshire, white wild fritillarias, wild anemones (one even flushed with the country) wild hyacinths, white cottage-primroses & vastwood-primroses.
I am quite unable before Herod as yet, but I travel into Arabia with Burton, & discover more & more how the man described by Josephus had the Beduin shaykh at the centre of his character.
May Day - o the gladness! And a little garden worthy of Flora.
Now to meet the Bride & the guest!

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 135; Vol XVIII, Add MS 267893, fol 67r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Written on May Day 94
She dies; it is our prayer that she should die:
With what sweet music shall she fall on death,
For jarred is all the music of Love’s breath
And she much hear all noises that pass by
Without His muffling wings? She will hear the cry
Of laughter from the streets: what the street saith
Rises through open doors: she shuddereth As one had stripped her to the open sky –
But who is this, with face that none may mark
Bows over her, & silent spreads the shades? –
Within her hand there is a flower that fades,
And a great grove behind the scepter shows
O Venerable, draw her to repose,
Keep her for ever with thee in the dark!
Marie is like a sod of green turf. When Tommy peeks, he will find the daisy, the grass, the wholesome warm.
The May Day is – as not before for years. From the terrace range on range of low hills, as only on clearest days everything soft & growing.
Alack! Heaven cannot just now supply [sin?] for the will: Heaven is doling out all sorts of festering foods.
How foolish is the narrowing of the moments! Brides & Priests, & Kings – the Blush, The Vocation, the amenity of God. We cannot see these things; & a rage of disappointment seizes us, when

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 136; Vol XVIII, Add MS 267893, fol 67v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: we come in after the event.

Marie is dusk, responsive to the country air as blue-berry. She has ableness of character - the true Protestant strain, & ability - her English is wonderful in attack - & a bright-eyed independence of phrasing makes one laugh as at the motions of a healthy living creature in the meadows.

Now & then she has the gesture - a trick of the brows that reminds me of Michael’s old friend of Paris days – Miss Gérante – who, strange to say, Marie describes as almost a “great-grandmother” to her! So it comes about we learn from Tommy’s bride how the good little soul, the sister of Michael’s supreme love - Alfred Gérante, came quietly to her end in the Deaconness Home, with pasteurs to pray with her, & by favour, her beloved objects round her - all her mementos. How strange is life - how strange! Tommy read the Gazelles - but badly, man of [????].

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 137; Vol XVIII, Add MS 267893, fol 68r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: I send my May Sonnet to Painter. The next day – Tuesday – he comes.

Yes, but the surveyor has left a lovely perfume; we are still agitated, & close upon Painter’s heels presses John. I decide they shall not meet. I am frayed with weeping; feeling already only the walls of me are left standing, - I must enjoy – so the devoted Henry discusses leases downstairs with John; & we in the sun – roam, speak of Dryden’s Antony & Cleopatra of Sabbatai – of [????] Duse [????] & the Sonnet.

He is disappointed in Sabbatai – because he conceives Renan’s Jesus, repeated dramatically in the central actions of his life. He would even have the cock crow thrice. He holds with Renan, there was absolute disillusion when Jerusalem was entered; he regards that Life as to itself failure.

But we have not touched that divine figure. Rather we give the uncertainty, the error, & forsakenness of one called, but not chosen - one who for a moment had confidence in himself from within - & then went about seeking a sign. In Christ [????] Michael, find a fulfilled Ideal, in Sabbatai the wreck of a man who is not a hypocrite - who is rejected - who cannot lay hold -
Every endowed & doubting soul is a Sabbatai. Sabbatai has [????]

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 138; Vol XVIII, Add MS 267893, fol 68v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: in him of the fluency of faith.
Painter has always felt profoundly the tragedy of Christ - he would have liked our Sabbatai to have something of his richness of allure, his tenderness. This was not in our scope.

We speak of Rossetti. “You are like him-” “No, Michael, Rossetti was one of the original minds of his time. I am not that. I am a spectator, doubted by the actor. That means I am a critic. I am the greatest spectator I have ever known.” Of his painting he will not speak, but much of its his life, in its current of change & fate -

He likes the Palace, it is not hostile to him. He likes its sense of solidity - that storms do not shake it. And he likes the mid-night landscape from those high windows – Kensington Gardens he does not like.
There are brief glances of Henry – but when I find her with [????] long after John’s departure – at last, after Painter is gone - she is fallen petals.
Yesterday May 4th, we kept my Mother’s wedding-day (70 years ago) with finer fritillaries than ever. Round the [????] portraits flowers grown in the garden clustered.
To-day my Dearest has been with me – gathering the long-peach tulips from

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 139; Vol XVIII, Add MS 267893, fol 69r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: our garden –bed. She is always exquisite in convalescence, & I am grieved to be but dull cloud to her gaiety.
I have written to Mary – “the leaves have come out gallantly. – but I hate the gallant leaves.
I love to see my dearest gathering flowers. I like to witness that action best in all the world.”
Philosophy.
If it be space that makes long distances,
Beauty it is that brings our joys to pass,
Drawing together that that severed was:
As a cut branch of blossom from the bees
Cut off, is, in its cluster, full of these,
The drag, & all the murmur of their mass,
So I behold the features in a glass
Wherever Beauty is, & smile at ease,
Feasting at leisure on thee, though thou lack,
Feasting at leisure, counting all thy praise.
So is it with thy love, I have thee back,
All thy perfections subtle in my gaze,
If I but look on Love – so am I sure
Of thee, while Beauty & while Love endure.
May 6th 1904.

p.hi: Tuesday

div.p: We expect Amy - I look out at a rap & see Fay’s pilgrim cloak. He has arrived on the top of the [pert?] Surveyor who has comes <been> to chronicle repairs, leaving my breast full of aspics.

He looks ill – like a white flower tired & purpling in its shadows: no question but he has had influenza. Another rap! I slip out to receive Amy, past a heap of Sabbati Acts a vol. of Anatole France & a vol. of Dryden’s plays. I open the door – . . It is John, with apple & cherry – flower from the Manor, came to read over the Lease. I draw him down into the Gold Room, where strawberries smile – swiftly order up <tea> to the Sun Room for Michael & Fay, & tea to be served with the [1???]. strawberries for John & me, excusing ‘Auntie’ on the ground of literary talk about a play. Alas, I miss all

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 141;

refreshment in ideas while welcoming John’s kindness & the touching blossoms. Amy, looking charming in green comes later to join the Gold – Room Party. When John is gone, Amy is sent for to receive the mannered greeting of Ricketts noisily bantering & filled with laughter. I am tired– tired . . .

Since then my adventures have been with flowers . . . Darwin Tulips of wine & oyster-violets, of peaches in awe at the satins they stain – great boughs from the orchard, pinions of a Sun of the Morning. . lifted strands petal over petal, flowers over birds – a ‘ruffle’ for flight on the wind that will carry them away. On Thursday little Dodge came, but danced about my nerves! tired & needing discreet sympathy. Mary

The hours of May have been cold – very cold in manner. How slow have the days been! I progress at first with the movement of a glacier – now with that of a wakened serpent or tortoise!

Meanwhile I am struggling with sickness, the Schedule of Repairs is sent by the Trustees, the cheerless Doctor comes to me out of our air good for neither man nor beast & over the River boards are set up offering sites with a river – frontage – our worst fear & anguish realized.
When Michael & I are together again we suffer the most excessive
crise des nerfs.
All day my nerves have been as tops & whip-card in a substantial tangle.
I cannot conceive in form our houses directly before our eyes.
I cannot conceive us without Paragon –
And I have a deadly fear of the country & the indigenous cow.
While Fay’s hate of Kensington Gardens is a warring against terror.

We have finished
Twelfth Night
it teems with Michael’s youth – – it is full of the honey & cloves of youth. Sweet, sweet fooling – sweet, sweet love-making & a key of music set from the very first.
Our beautiful yellow Puss Ruff has wandered. I love all our animals to be in fold. But today we have the gaiety of some kind of hope in us. Michael has even wrought at
Herod.
I have sent Act I to be typed for the garlanding of lovelier work.
A Snatch
It is the Spring –
O Eros of the Garden & the trees! There are leaves & unforbidden By a void my birds are hidden – Each bird a quick May-breeze: and the birds sing.

Anatole France’s Contemporary Books:
A Kaleidoscope of the fragments of today shaken into patterns, not by the hand of a child but of a much grown-up man. The irony alone is in the shaking – there is innocence still in the result.

We have from him mockery out of the very gentleness of civilation. He is not too serious for now – whenever there is seriousness in a man’s work the past preaches on the future idealises. Anatole France lies in the atmosphere of our breath, & sees the light
of
on our days & focuses it on some individuals,
watching how it characterises them with pervasive tenderness.
He is kind toward fellow-men as our sun toward the suburbs, the occupations of modern life. And in his light we can see a little light – for he is patient, & humorously deprecating.
Anti Semitism
Putting aside the influence of science, I believe that most of the irreligion of today is due
Notebook 18, Page Image 146;
Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 72v; Jenée Crayne

to suppressed Anti-Semitism. Judaism is Oriental & Christianity alone conquered the West by its foreign elements – all in it that could be affliated to Greece & Rome & the North. In the Catholic Church we have an Occidental Creation, full of the philosophy of Greece, the practical functioning of Rome, the old Pagan latitude &
beauty <
loveliness> the Western solidarity with Nature that man enjoys under temperate suns.

There came Protestantism to destroy, & to offer a Jewish Book for an European Church. Protestantism holds to the Bible & nothing but the Bible & it has gone very near to destroying Christianity by an Orientalism abhorrent to the genius of Europe.
The Wisdom of the World-Snake was in the Church of Rome when it withheld the Bible & disavowed its Eastern origin.
Peoples, like individuals, have a tendency as they age to revert to their early ideas & tendencies, & our developed
Notebook 18, Page Image 147;
Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 73r; Jenée Crayne
civilization will not endure a superimposed Asiatic dominance, but breaks away to the real & free sources of its inspiration.
Protestantism has done a dangerous harm to Christianity by re-attaching it to Judaism –
they must be severed
– if Christ is to be the Star, the Morning Star, of the white races.
May 15th
Chestnut Sunday

Chestnut Sunday is the biggest day in Bushy Park’s calendar. Each year, on the Sunday closest to 11th May, people come from all over London and the South East to join in our local tradition of celebrating the blossom on the magnificent horse chestnut trees in the park.
& “Mid. May’s Eldest Child.”
After a day of hot wind - a killing loneliness that
made the

div.p: debt - all the rest is a fortune. How cautious Fay is! - a hedge all round to keep ‘little Charlie’ safe from attack - a well-grown hedge of noble modesty, not a cowardly pallisade.
I suppose the photo gravures are the best possible, but the pictures were half-lost, & far more truly revealed in the text. I have read little yet.
As Browning said to us - I discrown no-one to crown Fay. He is a natural King.
Now of his last visit -

He breaks in at tea (Tues. May 10th) creative gaitey about his head like bees. He has been painting. On the settee upstairs we have Max Beerbohm’s Poets’ Corner. Fay draws our chairs into a crescent that we may all in enjoy it. Then such laughter! Divine laughter crackling like a god’s. He does not (as Michael says) laugh with us, but to & of himself; as the thunder thunders of the cloud. When he passes it is to sob with joy “O My God!” - or to ripple into encomium “It is a beautiful book - beautiful, beautiful” I think Rossetti in his back garden evoked

div.p:
the roundest agony of peals - Swinburne in his old maid’s bonnet of hair with his finicky mischief under Watts-Dunton
Theodore Watts-Dunton, English critic and poet, good friend of Algernon Charles Swinburne’s finger is a delight to kill with. Stupendous in cruelty & power is the Matthew Arnold-Whitman inciting the obstinate bird of freedom sets the laughter to such volume I only hear the tremulous shriek “this braces!”

The soft abundance of humour in the Omar & “Thou” does not liberally strike on Fay & he is not well-acquainted enough to realise the chalky perfection of George Moore face as he meets the Fairy Queen under Yeats’ encouraging arm. The little toes & legs of the good-boy-realist, his nice shining manners - ~ perfection, perfection! Yeats is a rather cruel caricature - though the attitude & pose are convince one’s deepest amuse-ment.
Max is a wonderful critic by distortion - the novelty strikes to the centre of a characteristic & brims us with delighted recognition of it.

div.p: May 21st

We have had adventures. On Tuesday- May 17th- we start for Upper Parrock Farm to begin with the tours out of the lunch basket- Bacchus
Bacchus: Roman God of wine unfavorable! As we approach Forest Row
Forest Row: a village in East Sussex, England we encounter lustrous country. The trees shine- the lie of the fields & copses seems to enhance the youth of in their spring brightness. But alas, our cab climbs in the wrong direction- away from enlightenment.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 152;
Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 75v; Kellie Saul

div.p: Even here the great speedwells cry out Speed well! The strawberry flowers are as lambs for the slaughter. Indeed all the flowers are ready for the butcher- so round, so clean fat! We drove up by a ribbed house that suggests colonial life, & wait on the grass, in our cab- while the mixen gapes on our side, & the yellow-ball flowers gape on us from the other. All is silence & great horror. Then at last the door opens & an ageless old woman in black with the manners of an unf underfed Cat, creeps up. Entering a door that looks as if no mere human soul ever passed it, feeling the fingers of a vicious guardian-rose plucking at me, I am in a little mouldy den of a hall- & then in a large colonial looking room an oak rafter the only signature of antiquity, & mould as of the family vault for atmosphere! Such a black chickenette on the soiled table-cloth & butter with the breath of mutton. A window fixed as the manure- yard & its central treasure-- the Well.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 153;
Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 76r; Kellie Saul

div.p:
As Fay would say - ”My God!” we left the violeted chick on its dish, & out on to the common grass! Our very souls stuttered before the mutual confession We must go. But the cab was away in the remote roads. We learn a telegram can be sent- we re-call the parted cab. Pussy behaves very well… has she not been stroked for five winters by old Lady H…. who has recently died at Hampton Court?
Hampton Court: Royal Palace in Hampton, Richmond, England So she understands those who have recently left the royal borough of Richmond! But we have to pay little short of ₤2... & the future is a blank.
Here follows bits from Michael’s letter to Fay.

“The old woman, our hostess, boasted she had “suckled” the herd of young creatures in the meadow.
