She had the guardianship of a Doctor’s son (species, I should say, idiot) whom she had set in her energy to build a greenhouse...When Henry saw the patient’s childish garden of polyanthums, rising out of the grass, she turned the head of our luggage back to civilization. Behold us at The Crown & Grinstead.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 154;
Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 76v; Kellie Saul

div.p:
our great excitement has been going over a fine Old Elizabethan house to let in the street. It has the most perfectly proportioned rooms I have ever entered, panelled walls, & a chimney-piece- beside a little dark-panelled library for all the world like the famous Supper-Room at Holyrood from the diamond panes one reads the date 1599 - about the date say of the “Sonnets,” & other sonnets might be written there-- but the repetition of the Rizzio
Rizzio tragedy: David Rizzo, Italian courtier became private secretary of Mary, Queen of Scots. Queen Mary’s husband was jealous of Rizzo and had rumors spread accusing Rizzo of having relations with the queen. He was murdered tragedy makes profoundest appeal to Michael’s imagination. Henry’s pale eyes burnt. I checked her by reference to a neighboring slaughterhouse, & refused to look at the folded eyelid of a fair, fair country beyond the diamond panes. Next Tuesday we start for a week at Court House Farm, Rottingdam (your old quarters) There I will allow Henry to open the Prado. Here I remember lines & verses of old hymns. The rustic dead have I suppose, left them on the air….

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 155;
Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 77r; Kellie Saul

div.p: I continue:

The chickenette is torn up, but not eaten- Then the hostess proposes we should have a look round, & presents us to a bode of free Chase on which a stable <confused> pattern if sunny green rests from the bits of underwood here & there. We almost yield to the wine of air, to that free Chase. Further, we see Louis Napolean’s fish-pond - without an imperialist desire to reach it. Food is rather a negligible circumstance here. It seems, just as the doctor is- people always have their health here. “But if you feel frightened <lonely> I would not have you stay.” The good woman drives off the young cattle & assures us she has suckled them all. There is no family here of human kind. But deep in bends I see a scrawled bed or two, & some polyanthuses
Polyanthuses: flowering plant that is a complex hybrid between the wild primrose and primulas in turf- they can’t be there by nature & if the ground is not the pure garden-bed their tufts are almost super natural. I shudder; & hear that the plot belongs to a doctor’s son, who had come here ill from India- sunstruck in the [into?] I opine. He becomes the denizon

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 156;
Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 77v; Kellie Saul

div.p: of Parrock Farm and the hostess or priestess & the suckled animals a temple-herd round the Idiot. When I speak of my illness, I am greeted with Nerves! Old Lady H… was never allowed to be ‘grumpy’. The keeper of the [home?]-farm,, the nerve-farmer… the lady nerve-farmer herself-- is a study- she has the thin lips & thin eye-lids, the cheerful thinness in the voice of a being of single experience-- Parrock Farm. She is original as the cuckoo [????] <wild-arum>, among the hedge-flowers… a temperament of curious colour & a noticeable quaint tongue.

The parted cab- back again & for us! We run on the grass to it; we bid farewell with hysterical assurances we shall never forget the kindness of the woman with our ₤2 in her black pocket & her troublesome guests going beyond the chance of giving trouble. But we nearly weep with sentiment! It is the shock of that cab, that reprieve in a mounted square, standing up by the mixen. We are light as air… The boxes groan over us, we are weak & weary, the world is before us

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 157;
Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 78r; Kellie Saul

div.p: unprepared for us -but we are light as air & jauntily accost these speedwells for their irony in calling up to us their interjections of encouragement to Parrock. Various inns are looked at & rejected… through the glancing Maytide we drive to East Grinstead & its Dorset... Cycle-motor manners there & no possible room! Am dead with weariness- the sensation of gyves round my knees… sewn on to the Crown we find goodness core-deep in the land-lady & her daughter, Joy. Every exaggeration of joy, for a harbour above a street, where man goes by & old houses still shelter the modern shops & shallow gray steps lead us up to pollard lorries- joy for all this! But the cost of this trying day is utter depression which lasts after a night of [assoupisonment?]. Whym is not well- he reports mood in fur. No-one knows where we are- We drive to the forest-- a glory of sun on the leaves where there are some… but the forest is a name & no wood-Gods rule or have forest knights there. On Thursday we seek out a lady- a distant friend, as it were, of friends--

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 158;
Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol 78v; Kellie Saul

div.p: The road is suburban- everywhere the retriever in wait for Chow & no-one at home…. But coming back we find Spanish irises growing with fresh stems & a sparkle of edges in <a> box of a flower-shop. Michael brings me twelve dewy [bannerets?] of flowers- misery is at an end. I begin to make our room more harmonious. I wonder what blossom will reconcile me to the Other Life- what tree over the grave a sweet plant will make me at home with myself. Then we seek & find the only green way out of E. Grinstead- the East Court Estate- of course offered for building sale. But, oh, the verdure of this May! How we have seen leaves- the plentitude of their shapes! There is grass to the feet & rooks to the ear- Each is the carpet of peace to a sense. And for the eye, there is greenness & a square red house looking on its distances unexcitedly. Peace-- perfect peace & abundant month of the May!

p.hi: Thursday

div.p: Another drive beyond suburbs into a community, so indigenous there is little wonder that Roman roads

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 159; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 79r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: are not to be found. What of the Latin could tread this [nisticity?]? The air is dull, a glorious dull thing - where are there any associations save the honourable local births, marriages & deaths? A forest, desecrated for iron-smelting, has left no boscage in the imagination, such as Keats says of to Psyche. Where is there a Genius in this large country there is only View - a complex of ground views or singleness of platitude?

But we enjoy the lanes - the leafy hedges, the herby flowers. At last we are on the ridge of [Ashdawn?] Forest. O air of a sea that has caught as its amber & seaweed the substance of the gorse-scent, the rocking of the pine-scent! In the Warren - little strewage of cones - Dionysus! Here we could be happy.
We cut through a body of air - this spine is a quick division of airs that are one in their Essence.
Below we look at Golf Links & a small house for borders, Kept by a charming creature - like a leafless stem in blossom! But how impossible to be among new

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 160; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 79r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: villas & [hicks?], in small surroundings!

After tea we go over Cromwell House - such a room there! The proportion of it a blessing - over a hundred little panels expressing its walls - a mantel-shelf 1599 - one high window on the O street, the its other ‘soul-side’ turned to the weald & forest - The passages mossed with damp - the poor garden cloked with quicken, full of set strawberry flowers - a cast-off firament of little planets.
Here a suckle of Scotch rose-trees in bud, there a giant white Columbine, with first few flowers, spirred spurred & profained in romance.
Upstairs the Cabinet Michael calls of Holyrood - a little reliquary to hold a Queen. . .
But the damp, the desolation, the shown garden -- & the slaughter-house! no, not here is the finger of God pointing us - save for a half-hour of ravishment.
We leave it for the green of East Court, blown over by a North Wind.
On the night Chow’s licking is joined by the lick of rain over all!
Poor Chow - poor Michael!

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 161; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 80r; Hind AlJarboa

div.p: The Crown Hotel East Grinstead
Whit Sunday. May 22nd
We have flowers of flame. We are growing well. Heaven, at [????], give us the life of the spirit.

This unloving of the old to wish to leave the earth. What have I, said Tristan, but my body & my country. To the earth, to our body, we bid eternal adieu. We shall be dearer loved of those who love us, if we do not want to die. We shall be less remorseful in heaven, if we have loved human things to the end — if we have been good, & indulgent to human things, as to the excessively old and childish. this ancient, honourable, earth, how good to be an inhabitant thereof. For a season.

Therefore to have witnessed this season <spring> of the gallant leaves is good, & many a saint in heaven may be sighing back to us. Afterall, the white robes of the saints don’t brush against the ground [ivy?] or cuckoo-pint
Arum maculatum is a common woodland plant species of the Araceae family., or the shut daisies.

The gorse
a yellow-flowered shrub of the pea family, the leaves of which are modified to form spines, native to western Europe and North Africa.-scent has brine in its blood. If Apollo oiled his locks, like the curled Antony
Marcus Antonius, commonly known in English as Mark or Marc Antony, was a Roman politician and general who played a critical role in the transformation of the Roman Republic from an oligarchy into the autocratic Roman Empire., he wd rub in a gorse pomade.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 162; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 80v; Hind AlJarboa
Whit Sunday

div.p: Very grey – but we achieve peace.
In the afternoon, going to East Court,
We see the sky [dove?]. like brooding over the expanse of country. and we visit a nine-years-old Garden round a red brick residence that proves how Love is enough—

it is spaced by rose-arches firm enough in leafy architecture for Mantagna
Andrea Mantegna was an Italian painter, a student of Roman archeology, and son-in-law of Jacopo Bellini. Like other artists of the time, Mantegna experimented with perspective, e.g., by lowering the horizon in order to create a sense of greater monumentality. His flinty, metallic landscapes and somewhat stony figures give evidence of a fundamentally sculptural approach to painting. to put his visions of stone in front of them. At every corner the loved herb, the cherished flowering bush, the adored plot of old-fashioned flowers:
colonies of columbines, Iris both high & low, [????] avens, rosemary— ah so many loves!

p.hi: Whit Monday

div.p: Morning spent down Blackwell Hollow.

A heavenly May-day! In May, there is a largeness of style in the Earth one does not get again till October – a diversity & sweeping of the light-something preeminently vital & therefore large in the aspect of the land— a beauty of expansion, before limit is reached, that is full of h infinite sway. The fields that end in harvest are but pile of green grass— they teem

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 163; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 81r; Hind AlJarboa

div.p: with buttercups, they skip with daisies – the trees that will be a slowly withering shade are now <but> lights to lighten the brows & pastures. The skies have sweetness of temperance as sense of [????] discipline makes them noble. and The forms of leaf & flower are innumerous. Birds fly & babble till the air has rillets of its own – singing by brooks. And there are all the nebulae of sound from the voice of insects.

Though we have been wretched at East Grimstead– with Chow
Whym Chow. ill & the air a melancholy outside us & drawn in, we feel kindness after taking the two ladies of the Montagne-arched garden to see Cromwell House. That parlour! so full of quiet ages when the home was nearly as quiet as the grave!
Nothing of the streets in it – a hold against them rather.
Then the brede of country between the town & Each Court is so full of greenery, full of mellowness & blossoming under sundown we feel contrition we have not loved it more.
The oaks are just in their youth – hung

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 164; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 81v; Hind AlJarboa

div.p:
as with Baltic amber
Baltic Amber is an organic substance, a “fossil resin” produced by pine trees which grew in Northern. – beneath them blue-bells hyacinthine
Hyacinthoides non-scripta is a bulbous perennial plant, found in Atlantic areas from north-western Spain to the British Isles, and also frequently used as a garden plant., the discord of a master!
To change the simile, this sharp thick violet is the right syrup to be served with the goldenly-embrowned substance of the foliage & shows earth a chef who can [dare?] the utmost.
Michael will remember from East Grimstead –
1) The daisies, the shut daisies, over the graves, on each side of the way where we passed with Chow – there they rested & seemed to wish to give us rest as they had found it. Happy, shut daisies!
2) The mead that was flowing from the sycamore-flowers, wet with rain, on Whit Sunday morning.
3) and a spray of hazel on which the nuts were but striplin leaflets with a queer little morsel of promise among them.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 165; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 82r; Hind AlJarboa
Tuesday

div.p:
In dense wetness we leave the Crown. such nice people – the rosy old mother weeping fresh tears over the cheeks her artistic daughter (a pupil of Herkomer
Sir Hubert von Herkomer was a German born British painter, and also a pioneering film-director and composer.) is now experiencing); the younger daughter thin & blue-eyed as a corn-blue-bottle, playing her piano, making good cakes, & bowing to her mother’s orders – quickly made by her effective orders to the house. We shall always keep in mind their human kindness.
Sealed up in our 1st class carriage we make a long, depressing journey.
Brighten at last! Always cheer in its robust conditions– immense sea, bright shops, houses too high to be ignoble, inviting donkey-shays & victorious.
The old downs, ugly, unchanged - there the roofs of dear Rottingdean!
[Count?] House farm – alas, spoiled by cork floral boxes, formality of beds – but quiet Mrs Johnson, the fidelity of quietness in her there is in the b beautiful lines of South Downs, to receive us.
Our rooms – nearly the same, but cut off at the folding-doors - & beatitude!
Rottingdean is to us as a Beloved – plain to others, a compliment of

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 166; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 82v; Hind AlJarboa

div.p: qualities to us – what we need, what we needs must love.
This power of places as of persons is a mystery.
behold we adore Rottingdean - we are happy.

Now we know the intensity of the wretchedness we have known. I wondered if I were too broken in nerve ever to feel natural joy again. Though I cannot stir from the house I lie & picture Fay by the mantel shelf like a Michael Scott be-wizarding Michael – or looking down the road I see his demon – motion, as if his cloak bore him over-ground.

and when we came down to dinner there is a witty, wicked letter from him to Michael. She had “begun to remember the lilacs were fading” on wh: she had sworn he should have his copy of the Prado
The Prado and its Masterpieces (1903) written by Charles S Ricketts back: on this he remarks “I do not intend discoursing on the moral aspect of your seizure of the Prado as I had intended the copy for you, Holmes having received a duplicate copy for review.” So the Prado is ours, even as

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 167; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 83r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: The Florentine Drawings –

I don’t know what makes us love Rottingdean so much - it is like true marriage. Others may wonder at our joy but there it is. The Downs set me in order as God’s command gave genesis to Chaos – it is fundamental as that.

We found that on the Weald the sheep-census equaled the human - the are <air> was rural & sheep-heady. Here the sheep are but a cloud or two on one element, Earth; while sea & air sweep the curly creatures limitlessly.
Michael writes to Janet -

“We are here among the rock-gardens & rose-daisies of Rottingdean. We are in this country of the Earth & Sky & air – a nightingale would know that she was naked in this country & be ashamed. But bareness in Maytime & the cowslip with a sugar-dew of its own, & at the sweet old florists where I used to get white violets for the artists, storms of purple stock & purple columbine! We have an wisteria I call the Flemish Madonna, & Henry calls her the Dove of the Ark.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 168; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 83v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Our news is most exciting. My copy of The Prado is with us. It is a glorious book – rich, invigorating, modest, arrogant & enjoying – full of exquisite, suggestive phrases & sentences. In a word I have the joy of recognizing the Painter as a Writer. How many Kingdoms he conquers! For the rest – doubtless the Eagles will gather together over the body of this book.

Another bliss has been to us Max Beerbohm’s Poet’s Corner – a series of divinest caricatures. One evening, just before we left Paragon, Painter, Henry & I gathered our chairs close together to laugh in chorus over Rosetti’s Back Garden [????]. But doubtless you have been to the gallery? In any case we possess the book & this & the Prado Janet shall enjoy when we return for [????] in rather mid-June. Dear Henry is re-gaining her famous Rottingdean beauty – a face as clear & placid as the seas. She is growing better, & is not only herself, but more than herself.
It is really two years since our last visit to Rottingdean: the infant just born (the fruiterer’s infant) then, has now eye-lashes that over-shadow

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 169; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 84r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: his cheek like sycamines.”
Wednesday 25th of May.

We wander about, about – after tea we ascend the White Way - the <several> planes of dawn are each stretches of vari-colours in their most delicate bloom. We meet the shepherd - cheeks like washed coral - dog, a young pure-bred Sussex sheep-dog, with Kindliness of eye, a pot au feu of goodness. The sheep are all ba-ing in their wattles.
Cowslips of the turf, never more than two together, cowslips on short stems, with a few large flowers cherished by sea-wind…we pick - the fresh little stems break like glass.

There is sundown over the slopes; & in the meadows the lit dandelion-clocks are nature’s Japanese lanterns for the fête - the daisies are become a presence, a multitudinous white half way up the grass, so that they seem to float.
We each stand by Burne Jones’ grave – that dear grave that taught me Tristan’s mood in [Parm?]
To think we were living with Cesare & Alexander when we were here last

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 170; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 84v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: And now our Bedouin Herod is taking the great air with us!
Tristan – Julia Donna & Caracalla - Cesare, Alexander, Lucrezia, & Herod the [????]!
What company! - & add the Artists.
Thursday 26
A thunder-cloud lies over our dawn all day, growling like a nasty old lion -

My vases are full of flowers, my brain of infinite curves & my chest of air - so the old brute may growl. We climb up to him, & he shrinks off, leaving a rill of breeze & a space of light where he has been.
Friday 27 May

But he is back at night – Oh! The heat! Whym nearly bursts with his pants, our slumber is a stifled & prolonged groan. The morning the sun rain – a vision of rain in the midst of blackness. The rooks have been disturbed - it is sacrilege; rooks are the genii of security.
Michael writes to Painter -
“Cowslip-time on the Downs & the grass at the closest mysteries. The rooks alone are wheeling about angrily. They are

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 171; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 85r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: mourning their murdered young – shot unaccountably & in glossy multitude they mourn on the wing – so I will not stay to be sorry.
Such a nice letter was laid on my dinner table on Tuesday. It fell in deliciously among the cowslips & soft brines of my mood.
Henry & I are now reading the Prado through.

Don’t write “output” - that is what Bernhard would do!! I cannot give you the right word…sometimes you can say work or production (or creation) “output” is vile, worse than “you have deceived me” in Sabbatai.

You have fine sentences hidden away like violets under their leaves. If one is impatient one misses them. More & more, with delight, I recognize in you the appreciation. Instead of cheap abuse, or apology, you make us feel the virtue, or, at least, the gift or attractiveness of the poorest little Artist. And I laugh at your struggles to be just to the Spanish school. Whenever you are really naughty you must be shut up there.
Would you like to hear the old florist from whom I used to get white violets for you has storms of purple stocks & of purple columbines? We have

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 172; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 85v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: memories at Rottingdean – memories of Caracalla, of Tristan, of Caesar Borgia, of ___
But it is lunch-time!
Michael.”

p.hi: Trinity Sunday.

div.p: Last night Michael stormed across my sullen sky - <for us> so miserable, so unnecessary! Only nerves… & the vast mystery of that which was & is & is to come lying lying before us in the relation of its Love!

Our feast retrieves its Vigil. The sky beams after thunder-rains - in the grass for mowing the blaze of the buttercups is such one can hardly look. And the grasses themselves are motes & web of planetary brilliance.

I re-read the Gold Tristan – an achievement in secousses de passion…but wanting its true end. All the scenes, except the death-scene, have reached that point where an element utters itself – that point in emotion when, like the cloud that must thunder, the cloud that must rain, the season that must be spring, the season that must drop every

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 173; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 86r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: spoil, need becomes actuality. In the death scene this moment – the capture of wh: is the method of the play - remains neglected. In fact it is avoided & a sense of levity triumphs.

The radiant morning glooms… Before tea, while at wonder in front of the house, we see a thunder cloud over the north, from which the air takes hollowness. A malignant pallor begins to turn Eastward… At our return the doors, the windows are all open as they are before a coming of death.

Afterward on the Downs we see the storm stream smoulderingly out to sea, while we are in a light of keen relief, almost a shimmer. Before the lines of down I pace, leaving Michael & Chow on a summit-mound & concentrate my passion on Tristan’s End. Gradually the vision of a new last scene forms, different from the fine situation in the Flame Tristan, where he grips the wall, supported by his old father-in-law & his old servant. It was is difficult to sweep clear of that so arresting group.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 174; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 86v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: May 31st. I write to Fay – from whom I have a charming letter – speaking of his horoscope [????], & complaining we must not treat the Prado seriously - “Get up, dear serpent, from your smallness Don’t play at being a small serpent, like your great hero in Paradise Lost. Be cloudy blue, & sorcerous, elusive at pleasure, so only you are not dwarfish for – listen, - I have a secret thing to tell you – destroy this letter – for Shannon must never read it – since I have been at Rottingdean – I have found written on my heart – not Calais – but Diane. Diane de Poitiers & the French Renaissance (for which I have been thirsting) the Heavens are with this theme. I hear of a vital book - speaking to me already from Bain – with portraits – But already - she is the Fair Rosamund of Age…If the stars tell you anything of her, your horoscope will be of supreme interest I am in that most blessed state of rest before creation – of which the Lord (in Genesis) knows nothing.
It is like the rising of the dew, & as secret…..
But, until “the prophetic Soul, the Uncle” does his worst, write to me, Painter, of the plays – The [Electra?], & The Phedre.
I am mad to miss them. We stay here till June 7th a 14th. Henry is growing so beautiful I must withdraw her from this air.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 175; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 87r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: It sets a halo around her. I am groowing nothing except fierce eye-brows to frighten the sergeant --
Be well, Painter, & enjoy the June. I have white-balls from Paragon. In mid June you shall have some of my gathering.
Michael.”
June 1st 1904
On our breakfast table [crusair?] Saint-feiu, milk-white [campion. And Bain sends the book.

It is the third book that arrives at Rottingdean – ① Tristam & Iseult ② Autumn des Borgias – ③ Diane de Poitiers. I found Diane graved on my heart. My grief is with Henri, bowed by this inexorable goddess.
“Je vais [???] appartenu parcegue je vais curious; je ne soufrir ai pas qu’an arret du Parlement me declare votre concubine”
La Seule Princesse.

p.hi: June 2
nd
Wed.

div.p: I write the Prologue to Diane – or rather finish it. It was begun on the first day of June in the evening. What a joy I have

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 176; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 87v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: To Tommy.

We are here in great happiness. We have learnt the May for the first time. We are more at home here than at Paragon. Tristan, the Borgias – Julia Donna have all profited from the sound drawing of the place. Here we broke open the seals of the Tristan Book, the Borgia book; & yesterday a wondrous book on a new & secret subject arrived. All the country is laid out in sheepfields & acts - the mystery is open – it is in the air, & in the circling of the wind.

In this god-child of Diana – this woman in whom all the elements of freshness & clarity meet & are operative. Like Art itself she is cold, & yet not virginal. Art to which all things lie apparent can never be virginal, & yet has the ice & cold of a chastity that is elemental. Diana is very like La Beauté of Baudelaire.
In to the Prologue all my bee-work of the last weeks, all I have drawn from Maytime has settled into poetry.
Michael begins the scene between Diana the widow & Henri the

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 177; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 88r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Spanish-eyed Dauphin of fifteen. Oh, these buzzing tranquil mornings of creation – Each brain & right hand at their proper joy!

p.hi: Thursday

div.p: A gray windiness - We walk far into the downs beyond the White Way. We are with the matron Earth, the nurser of crops - where she dangles the little green oats, & has the wheat asleep on her knees – no flowers yet obvious, except the campion, like drops of milk. How such a walk, while invigorating, fosters one! Earth has given her breast to one’s spirit as well as to the wheat. All The bread of Life there in its infancy, with the Power that has produced it, & one’s very being in <natural> harmony with as it breathes with them.
I write Diane with Palissy – Michael finds dear Francis the First in the room with her.

p.hi: Friday

div.p: Michelet cares – the protestant bigot, who cannot help negating the Renaissance – the Humanism that would not take up the attitude

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 178; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 88v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Of mind that <wh:> has starved man – till he is the ugly, motoring individualist of today. Michelet has details, viciously presented, that are illuminating – but truly if one had not Diane first in his pages Fay’s remark that there is neither play nor tragedy in her life would be justified.
The day veers & I am ill –

p.hi: Saturday

div.p: It is delicious to walk wake to our sycamine-tree throwing its leaves in shade on its bark, & sending out a hive-throng of twitters.
The Wind is a bright North-East after walking in the morning field I write Diane & [Ganjon?] by the cascade – Michael still works on her Titianesque Francis.

She has a letter from Fay, full of chat, as ordered, of Gilbert Murrey’s Hyppolytus. “I sat next to little Arthur, who seemed quite intelligent. We had tea together & got on quite well. He agrees that good tragedy is in reality good melodrama. He hates

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 179; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 89r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: any mock music added to verse, which is speech refined by intensity of mood & emotion.”

That judgement of tragedy is true in one aspect – that the appeal to the eye watching for movement on the stage must be melodramatic to arrest it boldly. And both Fay & little Arthur would be swayed by the peculiar mode of today – viz, the artistic. The world tries to see like the painter now-a-days, not to feel & express like the poet. Great Tragedy will have its bold moments of melodrama – may even have a melodramatic construction (Hamlet) but however good the melodrama may be, the tragedy is not good unless the creative mood behind it is essential & dominating & ominous.

We have had a letter too from Sturge Moore, about publishers – the all too necessary Evil we have to face. It is helpful – but, ma foi how it exasperates by a slip in taste! He tells us publishers regard us as the French tried to regard the Dreyfus case as a “chase jugee”. No doubt you will come up again as the Dreyfus case has” This from a younger poet to one of Les Vieux -

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 180; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 89v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: It is cruelly strange, now the noble shelter of the vale press is lost, to have to meet publishing as if we were young things of eighteen – we who have lived & suffered such experiences to give man a few more emotions.
But Tommy’s sting warms my inertia – the gold Tristan shall be published.
Sunday.
Glittering North East. Admiration is possible, not a mood.

We have seen a great thing - a land-sea flowing round its ship… the wind in live current of waters over a field of grass, sweeping it, lilac & silver& nipples toward the furled old windmill. Below the land-sea some stakes of a wire-railing & a quiet strand of buttercups – a golden rim to the billows of grass & the black sails of the mill.
One has a sense of such high vitality when movement is of a surface rather than a mass – when the blood-horse shivers alay his flank, when the aspen

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 181; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 90r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: trembles in its outer leaves, when a thought passes through the aspect of a forehead - or again when reflections move over things. I have never felt more the talismanic power of life than I have had in this flowing meadow-hillside, as an ocean above me.

I have two tall glasses full of grass-flower & <green> barley, bound round at the brim with ranunculuses of a Venetian opulence of colours & in a glass vase by them wide lemon ranunculuses with black eyes. They were gathered by our old, old man, who will suggest to one the weed-heap, who laughs at his own <old> jests as a babe laughs at the new world - a very feeble, amused creature, with the weed-heap not the flower-bed before him.
Now I will try to put down what I saw last week as the thunder storm drifted.

I saw a hall with three windows facing, the middle one reached by steps. All the windows wide open & the door under the by the fire place on the left & the door on the right wide open as the windows. Through the windows

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 182; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 90v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: a brooding thunder-cloud that growls low.

Tristan is seated against pillows in a chair by the empty hearth. Behind his form, like a strange glory, his great golden harp stands – across his knees the gold cover of the harp. He is asleep and alone.
Suddenly Iseult of the White Hands runs in - but stops arrested, by the open doors & windows.

“It will be today” she shrieks. Her mind strained by the effort to “stand alone”, to keep the secret she has overheard - breaks into madness before the omens of the open windows, the growling cloud. Light my Lightning, like the brilliance of a bird’s motion in the sun, shoots on her eyes - she shrieks & cries out. Her old father comes in, angry at her break-down, insistent that she shall go away. Finally he drags her out.

Tristan wakes – alone in the storm – the wind blows now, the doors close with a thud, the windows beat. He is alone in Hell - alone with his doom, that everything he does is sin, that he is in the velocity of a great anguish forever – in the confusion he feels Death is coming – intrepidly

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 183; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 91r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: he rises. He will die on his feet, erect - He is a knight - he loves, & death is not a thing he can fear.

The op closed door is opened - there are cries deep below “The ship, the ship”. Iseult of the White Hand rushes in, like a bird is storm, & is hurled by her passion against the sill - He stands dying… What is the omen of his death - is it cruel or merciful? The cry rends them him “What colour is the sail?”
With frenzy at its height, Iseult of Arundel tells her lie, & he falls, like column, straight on the ground dead….
I saw no - more.
Tuesday June 7th

A sea-day. The North-Easter crashes down on the place, so we take refuge under the cliff & I visit His Majesty the Sea for the first time. I do not like his glitter, his indifference - There is no living tide <flaw>; the shore is like a lion on his side after a good dinner & all about people burrow in the pebbles, sit about by boats or on machines, read their news-papers, or tie up their children’s clothes.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 184; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 91v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: All this smugness on one side of the infinite limit, all the vast indifference on the other! - No wonder I keep away from this grim contrast with a spiritual fervor on me!
Late I go in to the closed church, & am alone with Burne’s Jones’ windows-

That Jacob’s Dream is just the symbol of Rottingdean - as in a cypher its spell is rendered to the initiated. It is a place where one lays one’s head on refl restful turf, where one is at peace, while a firm ladder rises from the downs, & angels rustle up & down. There is no effort for the mind – it sleeps & is full of wings & presences.

I like that St. Michael, with the dear aestheticism of the eighties about him – his eyes wide like Tristan’s - his blood red shield & plume & banner - in the folds of the banner the Dove spread in blessing.
And I like Michael’s business. Like fight with against the jeweled malevolence - the little Dragon. Michael has been just before me, & loves

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 185; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 92r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: the little Fanning of Gabriel – it [jives?] the trouble of the annunciation (“she was troubled”) – the Angel not yet being through the door.
As we return home together it is written on Michael’s heart that we should try to get the promise of a grave here on St. Michael’s ground.

Death is so different if all its details are conquered beforehand. We should like to enrich this little church in some way, & to lie near it & the great Dream for those who are dead that flashes from its wall - Lux perpetua. Michael has written to the clergyman to come & see us.
Wednesday June 8th
The Wind - but of gray plumage.

Amy may come for two days – she has left us wondering…we have been passing by the mowing grass - the aristocratic clover holds itself veiled from the multitude, but in high-set colonies the buds of ox-eyed daisy grown white, as proudly. For the rest, flowers of no race - beloved hawksweeds & the like - shoot up in a few hours.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 186; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 92v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Michael writes –
Dear Painter,

I have nothing to record, but a long, wakeful night. I was left clear brained by the tossing wind. Through the long hours the nightingale & the cock sang to me. The occasional re-minder of Time, cheerfulness & not betraying rose up so wholesomely against the long liquid vibration of that other throat. The nightingale’s song comes up from a chalice of rich liquor; it proceeds from wine. There is no lament in it & the Greek story is all wrong.

I have privately preserved at the old florist’s a bed of ranunculus for you - the pale lemon flowers we love won’t come out; some shall come out in sheer tenor at Michael’s will – to manifest to you that Rottingdean remembers your feet of flame.

Painter, I like to hear of your plays. Soon you will be write some. But first I want you to paint me “a flight into Egypt”. There was one at East Grimstead that consoled me. The Mother with the Babe all to herself - & that Babe a predestined God - the way by wh: she travels in unknown, yet provided for - St. Joseph, careful,

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 187; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 93r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: anxious & allotted…
How mad are the artists to take such disquieting disgusting instants as the “Noli me tangere”? or Transfiguration, where everything is embarrassing & contorted…
Forgive me for being dull - it is the night with the nightingales!

p.hi: Michael.

div.p: Amy comes in the wandering cab after lunch before the letter announcing her. The first windy walk up the White Way leaves her silent from any expression of fealty to Rottingdean.

p.hi: Thursday

div.p: While Michael & Amy are sea-gazing Mrs Johnson comes in to tell me Rudyard is returning & will build a house on his own site, next but one to Lady Burne Jones’. So Rottingdean wil have its potentate as well as its genius Loci. I am excited at this triumph for the little place. And we hear that the old house above the church - The [Challaner?] will soon be to let. It has a heavily pannelled room & a chimney-stack through one of the bedrooms & a scullery where old farmers drink <drank> as the dramatists at

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 188; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 93v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: “the Mermaid.”
We have a destined feeling of home at Rottingdean.
…I wander by myself in the grass - <[????]> rain as from a vase makes the breeze cool.
I return to the Death-scene of Tristan & almost finish the new version.
Michael brings me violet fleurs –de-luce & white roses.

The clergyman comes to see Michael - a pleasant interview. Unless one of us dies here he cannot undertake our burial - but if we were to die <here> the grave cd be made large enoght <enough> for both. Not even to parishioners can he promise any special site…so we must hurry here for our end or live here.
Now the rain is come, as it always does, giving the sky sense of a stranger to the atmosphere - there becomes subdued & delicately mannered.

p.hi: Friday

div.p: Amy has a sog of heat to bear - I am very bad inside & house-bound. A silly letter from Tommy suggestive that through a woman he could get an opportunity of reading a play

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 189; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 94r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Of airs to a junior Partner - he also a budding poet. If he is interested he will ensure the play having a good hearing with his senior -
Michael replies -

“Merciful heavens, how can we thank you for this opportunity of being read by a “budding poet”! Out of the mouths of these babes & sucklings wd you perfect our praise? Not for one instant would I abide being sniffed at by these doubtful tomorrows, not one of them capable of considering the matter in hand. Surely you forget who have welcomed us who have given us their homage.

Browning told us to wait 50 years, & apparently we must wait. I asked you to help me & you have diligently tried - but an impossible method - as you should propose the pawn broker to me if I were in sore straits for money.
Like the Duke in My Last Duchess I choose never to stoop. But I choose to publish Tristan, & I will.
Sincerely yours
Michael

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 190; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 94v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer
Saturday

div.p: Amy leaves us, after an affectionate, little visit - very sweet.
We go out for a long walk up the Lewis high road into the folds of the Downs - the walk Amy loved yesterday.
There is rain about, & rain over downs is stealthiness over solitude. One is haunted.

Then the rain steals out of apprehension, & a wonderful singing of birds at a height from the ground, as it seems, of the tall grasses, takes its place. The great downs are tawny or dove - they lie so soft & wide. Here one learns that solitude has wings - they are stretched out here, where she sleeps - we can measure their pinion-breadth, we can stroke their irised plumage with our vision.
There are hollows where a God could lie naked & create, because his dreams are <would be> so generative.

This country <of downs> is perfect for us while we are incarnating Dianne. She was ample & plastic as [????] of a base or evil thing had to be done she [brought?] it, by the great art of her amplitude & sculpture

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 191; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 95r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Into a noble relation that purified it, as the Downs transmute a turnip-field. There was air on the bosom of all here deeds - light over them & a lovely gravity.

p.hi: Sunday, June 12
th

div.p: My new version of the Death-scene of Tristan is read to Michael. She realizes at once it is under command of necessity up to the moment when Tristan’s hand falls through the hollow of his harp…after that…well, anticlimax reigns. In a few moments she ends the scene - self-same with its beginning. The whole is an entirely new end to poor Tristan’s agony. Laus Dei!

The loveliness of today is heart-rending because we have to leave Rottingdean. Oh, why is the sunshine so sweet a flood - & the air, why is it of God’s nostrils - Why is the note of today In the Beginning - & we must go?
We sit at sun-slope hour behind a rick – the summer lies on the grass of grain, on the wiry clover-studs. Michael gathers holy clover - & we talk of Dianne in the

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 192; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 95v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: [severa?] gentleness of the hour.
Monday June 13th

Our last day, & as if to help us a hot & cold South-Easter blows on our nerves. A cold sweat of mist comes up from the sea – I put together the scenes of Dianne with Palissy & Ganjon, but the day is not of Art. We grow nasty with weather.

After the fret of packing & paying, we go to the Dianne Downs, round High Barn. How great is this Earth that has to ripen & shed itself of its crops, to receive the furrow & the seed before we are likely to look on it again in October – yet there is calm in that the least accent of hurry - trust & pervasiveness at their highest. I think my life in these terms - try to fix it to their influence. Then I think of Dianne, so tranquil when her King is dead - like the moon, full to completion of the dead sun’s light - a world in herself. I see her as I shall part from her - in the moonlight. That is as her orbed remembrance of the glory of

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 193; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 96r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: her love - she fills the world with her vital mourning, with her plastic light of consolation. She is the moon left in Love’s Universe.
We see a ring-dove by itself in a small cage.
We see a great dog running & a rabbit - they are more like two elements that two creatures in the play of their passion & rapidity.

We see tufts of sainfoin here & there, a tartness of carmine in their just-opened pea-blossoms. We hear the folded sheep as they baa ng <ba-a: it is> like the clanging of iron bells & the chittering of silver bells as ewes are answered by lambs.
We walk on the dim cut grass by the side of an elf-forest of wheat-stems & leaves - the dim & the sturdy sharp over against each other.
We come home to a delicious dinner - the chop & tomatoes & the gooseberry-tart are sweet & sturdy in effect as the wheat-field - we long to have more containing admiration - so good they are!

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 194; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 96v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Fay is in Paris, gone after Les Primatives [????], the new disease – We must not be surprised to see him next Sunday, not to sup.
Well, I must go to my bed now – I have been bothered by moths…Ah, if I could only stay on at Rottingdean & go on with Dianne!
This little place is the Lourdes of Imagination – it loses all its ailments, walks & sings.

p.hi: June 14
th

div.p: We part from Rottingdean on a a day of sultry westerliness.
Dear Mrs Johnson continues humanly the effect of the Downs themselves on us till we leave Brighton Station. Then we unfold her egg-sandwiches, & their nourishing gentleness continues her influence.
We are delayed by [????] trains. The air is morose with heat & damp.
Rush the soldier has proved dastardly in faithlessness & forsaken the dogs.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 195; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 97r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Never has Paragon been such a white economy of loveliness among its manifold leaves & its stretched curtains of roses. The green & white striped curtains <hanging> are clean & the matting like a Jap. Welcome to the new year. The maids have had a portrait of music when they guard under ivy wall, most successfully taken by Herbert – all so grateful & lovely, yet I am sad. The air weighs on nerves I must confess turned [parlons?]. How hateful are the follies that play about over the abyss, when nerves are chaotic.
I put irises of brown banners in Murano glass – This does not comfort me,
We sleep in blankets of combed wool on feathers piled like the living breast…in vain! I wake to lease – no Rush – summer haunt – Publisher [????].

p.hi: June 15
th

div.p: But after a few hours collapse the new force asserts itself. Michael seeks town – I work out our accounts…there is great improvement this June.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 196; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 97v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: I take Whym on the Touring-path, meet the Rivett-Carnacs, look at their old garden roses next door, bring Lady Rivett into our garden with its new ramblers – its curtains of glowing hybrid-teas, & after she has left me, I cut roses, bringing in an aromatic heap that challenges vision & nostrils alike. I am really happy today as I always am when not bothering about leaving Paragon.
The joys of faith seem to be vouchsafed when one does not seek to betray one’s heart that loves Paragon.
Lady Rivett says whenever Sir James is [limp?] he swears he will let the house – as soon as ever he is better no power will make him reject it. ‘Oh, you’ll stay, you will see!”

Michael comes back from the peacock room – charmed by this little cosmos of the Eighties – the peacock on one side repeated in the mirror opposite, as some effect on that wall such an exquisite bit of economy in joy!
She must write of the peacock.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 197; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 98r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: [????] then she [????] to the Siennese Exhibition, has made me laugh with the fantastical self-revolted attitude the madamas, their baby has been suckled on suet-dumpling. Michael was tired & her mind simply vicious toward the poor Siennese.
Paragon June 18th.

My Beloved is as brave as a Japp. Controlling nerves, she has been with me in town & again at Tommy’s often. Eye-bright happiness is with Marie. From Marie’s mother I learn how Eliza [Géreuhe?] died. God is pitiless to his virgin old. They die in solitude. She died in sleep. That is to die unawares.
I love my Paragon, I love the shrine, for the rest I am as dumb as a midsummer bird.

p.hi: Thursday, June 6
th

div.p: To town to see Whistler’s Peacock Room; magnificent tour de genie! Ah! How good it was to be alive in the late 70 Seventies & the Eighties - such enthusiasm, such adventure & romance in Art - The Japanese Victory – The Aesthetic Triumphs - all the Artists fantastic & gallant,

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 198; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 98v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: yet always artists! And I was young.

Dear Peacock Room! Typical of our Inspirer, the Peacock, the bird of the great green of Heaven. He set our scheme of colour, he watched us from his bronzes as we accomplished our Dream in our little Rooms - his blue was our firmament, his green our Earth, & we knew of no nil nimbus so victorious as his - the glory of the saints & the Rose of Paradise were melted into one gilded flush of rays for this Paraclite of aestheticism.

And here Whistler has set him up for the ages - superhuman as a Buddha on the shutters we have him swelled into godhead - his tail became a second heaven, his eyes at last one eye - that of the World, or of God.
He is the fountain reaching Heaven from its earthly source. He is Vision having reached Wath Wordsworth’s “bliss of solitude. Then on the great wall panel we have his drama, set religiously before

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 199; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 99r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: us in gold. Here as Oberon & Titania he braves his mate his double, & she braves him! Mutual jewels flash at each other from their eyes as they shriek –
“[????] met by moonlight, proud Titania.”
What, jealous Oberon!
Tarry, rash wanton: and I not thy lord?
Then I must be thy lady!"
So the great drama of passion goes on among liquid stars licked-up stars, flashed phospor, eclipses of crescents frecklings, streaks, bars & golden mail, such as convulsed Lamia.

And every where over the common place, uninspired Room the divine peacock exhibits an epos of his power - dazzling thin form with iris-colour, filling corners of dizziness with the glance of half an eye, the roguish divinity! - yet never forgetting the pomp of his essence, the amplitude - not for the second of a moment.
Hail Whistler, court-Painter to the divine Bird of Heaven! What Jap.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 200; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 99v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: sence of the value of spaciousness <& of> that suggestion of the illimitable in nature by a detail of Art - a symbol! Every decorative stroke is organic. I have seen nothing in Jap. Art more vital than the angry trains of the mates - not lashing the eye into sympathy by line only, but by organisms - & decorative life in the mass.

All Hail, holy Peacock - Bird of Rossettian Creation - Bird of the Japanese Victory in the Nineteenth Century! And this Peacock Temple & its [ichans?] is going to leave us for the New World that never knew our native ecstasy!
Are..[????] vale!
We have an afternoon hour with the Sienese school at the Burlington Fine Art.
The Early Sienese in the subject-pictures have a passionate emotion that has is expressed with sensitiveness too austere in the best masters to be hysterical - yet a thing of beauty & of the nerves.
The attitudes have an emotional

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 201; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 100r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: value in some of Duccio’s works & Larenzetti’s that a great actor might be inspired with. The [Reusan?] Dussios & the Crawford Crucifixion are dangerously charged with realization of the heart. But how noble - how feelingly rich the contour of his Christ’s head!
The Sienese Martini from Liverpool “Christ returning from the Doctors to his parents” is a delicious picture - both in heart and Humour.
Poor St. Joseph! He finds it a business to bring together the sullen fair-haired God-boy & that mother looking up queenly from her book of Hours.

We have looked in on just had a glimpse of Holman Hunt’s new version of the Light of the World – it us a jumble of Vision & Illustration. The face & set of the form are intensely beheld – all the rest is an appeal to sentiment. Even the figure & face make appeal - How different all this from a Sienese panel (attributed by [Langton?] Douglas to Bernard da Siena - whoever that may be) of a Christ in seamless red robe - with lines sweeping as

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 202; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 100v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: mountain hues who tramps the Universe with his cross, immutable in sacrifice, calm under his paramount destiny, followed by the prayers of a little monk no more asking them than the sun fulfilling his course or any other journeying element.
He steps on, the Cruciferous - the God - the timeless.
The Liverpool Preaching of S. Bernardino - whoever painted it - is a little gem of life & life’s jewelry. The blown trumpets by the high altar give a glorious sense of Voice to the old man’s sermon.

Two portraits of Women - the maid bust by Matteo di Giovanni & a full face attributed to Benvenuto di Giovanni – are finely dressed & deserve study for detail as well as for their very direct drawing.

Then at the end I came on delightful Beccafumi in his Clelia. Strange how Siena caught colour & movement as on a breeze at the end of its art-life in Beccafumi - as mightier Venice did in mightier Tiepolo!

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 203; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 101r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer
Friday, June 17
th

div.p: We pay Tommy a visit. We are forced by train to be early – we find Tommy in proof, so we wait in the pleasant green drawing-room while he gets into print. There is a lily growing in the corner. I feel as if a ghost from Paragon living there.
Marie comes in - a topaz. Yes, she is a topaz! “Her <bright> eyes Reign influence & cheat the skies” she has shone herself into marriage.
She has on the dazzling pendant of Fay - a loveliest Psyche & Cerberus well-necked, among scattered garish light of sapphires, carbuncles, sky-blue enamel, emeralds, a rose-topaz.

Old Mrs. Appia tells comfortable things of Miss Gérante’s end. She, of course, expected Michael to wear a bonnet & protestant elderly strings…she sees a fiendish; gay creature in a black & white Dürer dress & a wreath of little white pompon-roses! Lutherism has too much of the art art-nature to endure such disillusion. Tommy’s

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 204; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 101v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: oyster-white Room has the glory of The Samaritan on its walls. Ah! The sky is more broken & more lovely, but the wholeness of mood in the compassionate head & the sky as at first painted is gone for ever.

p.hi: Sunday - June 19
th

div.p: Fay comes - not fresh, but stale from the Primatives. The love of one’s life becomes a momentary torture in face of the Paris motors [????].
Both the Fellows are out of sorts & snappish.

I receive Fay & we sit & talk ailments…to us enters Michael in Dürer dress, charming hat of little white roses on profound black straw; & with some Blush Ramblers in her hand - Poor Michael! As she says after the found the two beings she loves best in the world sad & [????] amazing, like very old people. Her work is before her & her wreath <on her> she does it <her work> - the visit is made!
The wreath does it, & admiration, are the elements in life, is graciously present.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 205; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 102r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: We speak of retiring to Rottingdean by & bye – not yet. “It must be never” rules Fay, & explains this the irony of his old remark on residence at Rottingdean “How intelligent!”
Fay brings as gift his Bibliography of the Vale Press – a work as haughty & cock-sure as Swinburne’s preface to his Works.

Something turns conversation to the feeling of smallness one has in a crowd & Fay, with that gravity wh: is an emotional value in itself, speaks of the depressing tragedy of a crowd. It is not that he pities or has any active charity toward it - No, it is a sense as general as that of going through a grave-yard & reading the epitaphs. A motion of terror comes over the one at the thought of the place taken up by these, the trouble to feed & clothe them, to keep them alive for such a little time & to so little purpose. And it is terrible to belong to such a race, with its brevity & fuss, & the inconsequence of its lives. The voice we listened to took on a grey timbre, like a curfew - a sense of style on the

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 206; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 102v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Air.

When we come upstairs, Michael, fearing restless behaviour from Chow shuts him out by one door…the little flame of a creature comes in by the other Fay springs up & opens the door again most severely; but Chow stands & looks, & Painter looks at him. I shall always see the bland duel - Painter yielding to the sovereign quiet of marvel in Chow’s gaze. Routed he suggests “The Balcony, Chow!”
And the passage of arms between the peers is a thing of the past & of memory.
Michael is found out to be so innocent she confesses ingeniously to these crimes –
a) She sacrificed her Fellow to a mother-in-law (Mrs A.)
b) She asked a Bride if she saw much of these Artists - a Bride who shd never think of anyone but her husband.
c) She sent out an innocent Boy – Herbert – with two corrupted Dogs (Rush, having habituated them to the Bar at “the Pigeons”)

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 207; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 103r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: “success,” Fay remarks, “is always innocent” – à propos of Gladys Deacon’s wicked French songs.
Ah me! Painter posted 14 letters on his way here! What is becoming of our hermit? And all next week he is deep in engagements.

He has been deeply interested in Herbert Spencer’s Autobiography - it has explained to him so many things in the English middle-class mind that he has never understood - the genesis of so many of the minds that issue even into distribution from the middle-class.

p.hi: June 24
th
Midsummer Day.

div.p: The weather is the very atmosphere of this day seven years ago – we are in the gold, in the pregnant silentess - even solitude - of deep heat - among the roses & the haunted air of veritable midsummer. What a figure of Romance the dear Father’s was! With all his living passions warm under the tent of his silver hair

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 208; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 103v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: he went on into the Unknown lonely as the desert Saint, magical as a Fairy Thrall – on this day of strange contrasts to the imagination. Amy has sent from the Manor Garden a box of Martagon lilies - creatures of lustrous mourning purple, denizens of the Swiss Knolls, con-necting England & [Zennatt?], at a time when we feel that the Matterhorn is the mountain of a dream country, where Tragedies have their immortal being.

What privilege to think of one’s dead in a mountain country - so far from the death-bed, the medicine-bottle - in the amplitude of air, in sight of everlasting snow, waiting to become wholly of nature, under cover & under the blossom-dropping charities of a forest.

There was were in Father the personality & the Epix characteristics that would have made him <in the early world> a Hero or genius to be worshipped with the untouched victim due to the dead. Fascination would have hung round his dark ritual - his grave would

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 209; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 104r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: have prophecied. He was strong in kinship with the Fates, & he was faithful as those are who centre on influence. He has not left a memory, but a spell.
The men we know all believe that a woman’s one need is to love a man - that is enough, for it is her ideal.
They think so…

But woman’s own ideal is to be loved - she wants herself infinitely surpassed, her power of loving left behind by that in man. This is why she is religious & Christian – this is why the man who loves is her adoration, & her dream. Father had this talisman - he loved. Sorrow & bitterness & jealousy made desolation round his love - but the women he loved never forgot his love. It is a prodigy - like a well of sweet water in the midst of the Sahara. Is the living oasis ever forgotten _ is it not pondered on & dreamt of by the wanderers over thirsty land?
He had <in his gospel & as a lover> the great secret by wh: the son of God bewitches a universe.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 210; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 104v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Michael & I have been on the Towring-path & seen a steam-launch full of holiday-makers loose from the key & quay & away! It is so hot, the heat throws itself down under clouds to drowse.
The flowers have an apprehensive sense of their frailty - one sees their dread in the midst of their beauty.
I mun I must now return to Tuesday, June 21st, when we visited Van Wisselingh’s little gallery & found Fay there a master.

His Victim is suggested by the woodcut in The Parables - but there the noble figure is shut in by the violence, the ribaldry of the crowd - Now the figure in the Art of Sacrifice, is set before blue mountain-hollows, & an ideal escape into the limitless is provided by Nature. The toss of the Barchant-crowd is rendered in a large style, the colour is glorious - of the October Vineyard in its browns & smoldering reds. I hear the figure of the barrel

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 211; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 105r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: is held to be unaccounted for, & in pictorial treatment that rejects facial expression, the leering Demas on his Tub (of The Parables) is not recognisable in the bowed down head of this other. Here we have the stupid awe - a sort of animal contrition - the crowd shows when its destruction <of a noble thing> is over. This sin-laden habitude in kn the Ring-leader’s figure with the careless blank child beside it, seems to me a piece of time stability in the conception of the picture.

But the victim is Sacrifice - he is an incarnated act, felt perhaps more profoundly because he does not hang as is usually on the Cross, but is giving himself to death more actively with the air & mountains beyond his pain.
The picture abides on the heart, where it has vision.
There is a little centaur-picture. The young body of the Beloved reaches up, among the careful hoofs, to the centaur’s mouth in a kiss that springs from the ground to the height of its own life – a

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 212; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 105v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: fountain’s attainment.

Again in the little thing as in all Fay’s work the construction of the picture is emotional - & therefore we have a noble organic art, an imbeing that shapes every detail, that dominates colour. Cold little thing! - how his work moves me!

There is the Shannon of The Bathers, I have seen twice - also two little groups of women against gray, with in lovely attitudes, kept simple by their intimacy. A lemon as the amphalus of one design is an enchanting motive of colour.
His picture from the Apple-Orchard lithograph is debonair - the colour festive in a midsummer way, but the mystery, the heart of the mystery - is gone.
Shannon’s pictures are self-reliant; Fay’s are polarized from a source of Emotion - Shannon’s never take you beyond their own beauty - Fay’s strike you as with the breadth of a universe.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 213; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 106r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: In the same gallery there is a miracle – a Daumier sketch of Sancho Panza solid on his ass, that stands motionless as a little cloud of the night, & Don Quixote, flying through the rocky valley in a very moon-shine of rapid motion - all full of suggestion & infinite in its rhapsody.
A Monicelli landscape - a rare delight - has a breast of Earth moulded with love & a tree that stands forth as in the land of the Eternal Ideas - a tree & a dream.
At Toplady’s I buy an Egyptian amber necklace for my Love - fair in colour <as the evening-primrose.>

On Wed. June 21 – we meet a cousin at Louie Ellis’ a thorn-bush. The pretty lunch in Louie’s red dining-room has the blight over it only kinship knows how to spread…still more doleful Hertford House – Individualism in a collection is a failure - there is the monotony of one mind, of one effort in this house of [Sirres?], among these crowded pictures even the Benchmen cannot make joy dance in one – only the profound & melancholy Velasquez – “The

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 214; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 106v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Lady with a Fan” can arrest one vitally. There are nerves of vision, & beyond them a personality at the back of those orbed eyes, so ugly, yet jewels.

I learn how to finish the amber necklack, given by the sultan to a lady - & just brought at Harvey & [????]. The sultan has had the bad taste to have <hang about it> coarse gold tassels finished by amber nine-pins. Here, I learn of the bow & one bead hand hanging below it.

p.hi: Tuesd
Sunday June 26
th

div.p: Tommy & Marie came to supper. The pendant [???? ????] glows, <its rose jewels> like the almond & peach blossoms on southern azure.

p.hi: Tuesday, June 28
th

div.p: Dr. Will Sturge comes down. He demonstrates my trouble is functional not organic, but, spite of his wise presence he makes the mistake of telling too many tales of sudden accidents to motor & sensory nerves _

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 215; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 107r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: he speaks of <”a> warning”, & the twilight time <of life> I am entering, after full-work time. He leaves us well-assured & thoroughly unstrung. So may wisdom err.

p.hi: Thursday, June 30
th

div.p: We dine at the Palace - The air of the evening is as the touch of amber - safe immortal softness. And the welcome at the Palace! - Roses, stocks muted in purple as if sea-pearl were over their dye, mignonette - a Feast, carefully bounteous-asparagus that has been fetched from Bond Street in the sun. Shannon looks fine in his summer lightness of dress - the touch of austerity is broken by it, & his form touches Greek grace again.
Painter -
July 13th the Forest
It is Every [Dawn?] forest - the heart & centre – the oak leaves making a very crown, all round our head. With all on broken nerve-ends we strolled into the forest.
“And valley lawns beneath the waving trees.”
What glades, what golden beeches! We plunge. Ivy-leaved verenicu campanula meets us at the entrance - then the

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 216; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 107v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: lucky vervain.

In the evening, we seek again the forest. “Henry, I have found spied a spiritual lawn”, I cry - & Henry drops down into [????] gold. We are very happy: Henry fills me with most strong delight by smiling – Diane is in these shades.
Saturday
To-day everything is changed, cruel south thunder-gales have swept through the land.
July 20th Wed.

Yes, the Forest here is Over-forest – (Über-wald) a super-sylvan magnificence. The sun is in a creek of forest - all the great oaks & beeches besiege us. Last night the lightning flushed & tingled the tree-top horizon & mountain-sides of thunder fell on us in avalanche. But we had the great bedroom illegally taken from us on Tuesday & we swept - oh, like Adam on the first moss.

We waked with the wish to live on our bed. I was stark & dumb with over-bearing fatigue when I got here. The first morning we went along a rooty path, & at every step I grew more miserable. At last I broke down & wept as I

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 217; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 108r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: rarely do. The same afternoon our Land-lady said we were near to Bank. Michael looked at me. Now we had grown confused in our minds & had asked in two letters if Leigh were near – they replied they did not know its situation - so we concluded all was well. But at the mention of Bank, we realised our error. By cross-questioning we discovered that the rooty path was the woodland way to Bank. It is indeed strange. I thought I was going crazy on that rooty path.

Of course we never go that side of the woods, & we refer to the place as “where the wild thyme blows”. I had remarked to Michael “I like all the woods on the other side, but I can’t abide these woods.”

I am not a bit nervous or unhappy in any other part of the forest. On Monday afternoon we drove round by Stoney Cross to look <in vain> for rooms Actually this kettle-of-fish-year won’t let us have peace in the forest & we have to turn out of our comfortable rooms on Friday, July 29th.
Stoney Cross is just the same as 20 years ago – except that the sun is

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 218; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 108v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: new & exists for the millionaire & not for the poet.
This is one of the spots on Earth to show to an angel.

It was moving to stand after 20 years of work together by the Rufus stone, with plighted hands as then. So clear that living past - as yesterday. Rather weary to think of that early fame & the 20 years & now, except for a very few of the minds of England, we live unknown. Sic Transit…yet I felt firmer in real possession than in these early days. And we rowed Dianne – our last forest drama to the Power that is in forests…..

At this moment roses come from you & Amy - such wild roses to break on us in their fresh crimson & gold till we are out of countenance with their reality & think of them as dream-flowers, as Rosae Mundi. Such [bowing?] of buds! Boldre or Cadenham have no such tints, no such sweet jets of summer pulsing among their leaves. No, no! –
But they have whole nations of ivy-leaved campanulas, silent bells lifted under ferns, while the cattle make fay-music above with their

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 219; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 109r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: foliage-hidden bells.

And I have never written about that last night at Paragon - Bernhard such a sweet little thing, wholly himself, & living over with us the days when he was “so miserable & so happy” & he was giving us his crude, young doctrine in its insolence, & glory - the years of the red-cherry of La Grande [Chaminiere?]. And now the house is gone & the cherry-tree: but we the companions in the spirit remain. He said the days at Kingshott last year were some of the happiest & most precious of his life. He met us with a kiss on our hands as they clasped his; & he was caressing & he admired from the first “you are beautifully dressed, Field” he said touching the black taffeta with black & opal rushes, that brought Shannon’s instant acclaim of joy. Michael, in shimmering gray eighteenth <century> gown, was praised as she reclined on the little sofa “How Mme de [Recamier?]!” At dinner he spoke of Versailles en artiste – deliciously bringing out its power…that it would teach nature a way - give it a supernatural aim, set before it

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 220; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 109v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: the ideal of arcade, arbour, grotto, fountain. He was staging with Miss Marbury - the great entre – provense, to whom Oscar give us a letter! He found her a large creature, full of life & life’s experience - a business-woman, with a massive Beyond. I’d wonder if after all, she could do anything for us] She lives at Versailles, & all the secrets of the ideal proposed to nature, all the more hidden persuasions to its wildness to become art were open to Bernhard.

He talked of poets & painters & how most of them are “pockets” of gold - only the very greatest - veins. Hence their early work is a moment - they only iterate after. Swinburne was ever the poet of Poems & Ballads, singing of death out of the very superabundance of life. So with the painters of the salon in 1902-4…They were pockets - they are just where they were then. But Shakespeare & Milton in their old experience are prophetic & not the sum of their youth.
Then for long we talk of red-cherry time, & Bernhard confesses how im-

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 221; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 110r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: portant we were to him - how we cared for us, but apart from that we “helped his functioning” - far more important than anything else!! His Spanish Countess now is where we were then - but he is far away as we are & therefore we are for more vivifying. He is not yet able to work but he is sure it will come all right, he feels such volume of thought-capacity behind him…But all the while the little thing is thin as a bird & seems to go to the air for his sustenance, having left off wine & coffee & most meats.

Early in the evening he referred to having just seen “the one & only artist” - I stretched mind over the world; wondered if it were Rodin, & then Michael solved the phrase - “Oh, you mean Ricketts” & we laughed at the rival’s irony. But just at first the eyes (that used to be ‘blue [????] weather’) looked very gray, with a thunder-knot in them, till our greeting & mood told him he was ascendant.
I am still weary in head, & I find it impossible to set down the charm

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 222; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 110v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: of the Doctrine - the mellowness & soft [contrition?] before the larger years for the glorious brilliancy of youth & its inadequacy - the intimate bind of so many years between our spirits, the throwing of himself on the mercy of our interpretation & seasoned love, the paths of his frail appearance & high laborious dreams.
Religion is more & more to him - inevitably the Jew. He spoke of himself as “placqué centre à l’Éternité.”
We had converse & touched across infinitude.
This Valley of trees over wh: the moon rides at twilight!
We have been here at our new Forest Inn, Emery Down, just a week yesterday.

The wide breaks we find too open for the gods, who only come close to us in obscurity - from pressed under-growth, or profound shadow. Here the shadows have space to dance on, & the veiled Divinities retire to the Forest Enclosures. Only on the first day did I feel the steps of Dianne close. And we are too deep inured in

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 223; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 111r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: trees for the air of Poetry to reach us. We must wait till we are in our new rooms next Friday with their breezes from over Stoney Cross plain. Francis is with us - at a word we [buried?] this tasselled gentle to our side - he is infinitely right to live with no tax on one - less than that of an animal; even in moon, humourous in the reception of the day’s happenings: hot rapturous & disturbing over scenery, always with the apt word & the amenities of humanism to give art to life. He is a great acquisition.
This morning he is seeking at Bank for psychie revelations concerning Culter - the object of my spirit-shaking Premonitions. He suggests that Culter was a true nom-de-guerre _ a Knife.

We drove along Stony Cross plain yesterday in gray-coated weather, of perfect tone with the plain, & with the masses of beech & fir. The air was as a strong enchantment; & our aim was Sloden - the old British Bury<ing> ground, with yews above, we reached from Browning four years ago. As before I was spelled by the valley over wh: Sloden lies down. The Dead are in it - the mould it

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 224; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 111v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: appearance by their resting places & by their resting from the old years till now. The yews cling with their obduracy to the slope, till the wood is tight on the ground as a corded tent. It is dedicated to the Earth service - it is awful, it is close to the soil, low down on it & sepulchrous! The yew-stems flap their skin on their ancestral thews - like everlasting snakes casting their skins to the centuries; & in the valley itself the curves have the infinite bountifulness of the burial-mound - womb-like, fostering to the imagination - and there is a width about the air as if for big souls to pass about & drink its ever-renewed freshness. There is The feeling <is> in it that Wordsworth has seized in Ossian’s Grave. The actual features of the spot [????] its one as a Dream comes through sleep - reach the brain where it is remote, where it has seen things from the beginning of the world.
Whym Chow strained after rabbits - when we were with him last every step was a pl pain at my heart, How good to move with slowness

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 225; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 112r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: only & no pain! We must haunt Sloden & the Dead again.

Being at the heart of the Forest here, we realize it is a casket of balms & myrrhs & odorous gums - it is just a casket of spices, & the heart of the forest is embalmed. As we came to it in the evening its fragrance is solid before us.

Francis is back from Bank. He claims to have laid the spectre. No such name as Culter is or has been known. And the honour of this user of the knife is made free with - his name timed into the mere producer of knifes - Cutler (even this re-arrangement of his written name brings no real being to the local memories) & at last the suggestion comes that his name is that of some lady-lodger. How are the mighty fallen!
We never thought is might be the cat-like female assailant, & I swear by Hecate, it was not.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 226; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 112v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer
The Second Sunday

div.p: The top story of Paragon is finished. We have heard that Bernhard has been called to Paris on business. So not no Forest meeting! There is such a small element of Time in my relation with him I scarcely feel this check. We reached the perfect moment ten days ago & within the radious radius of its perfection all time is included. Had he come fretted to the Forest - had he come conjoined, not his single self, all my future might have become temporal, that is now infinite.
He returns Tommy’s Poems unrepentant - he still feels as if they were rather promising, but hopelessly unmusical exercises. The utmost they extract from him is a certain consent, but with no warmth.

The last criticism is merited to a degree - Tommy’s hateful mind chills the creativeness of his emotion. But his work is not promising - it is performance - it is a little satyr of Pan, not a little Apollo or Hermes - still the whole God, born not in the womb.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 227; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 113r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: We are cheered by a delightfully confidential letter from Fay - Mary’s single visit - the Pelleas & Melissande of Sarah & Mrs. Pat - these are lightly evoked. Also by post comes a little snap-shot of Bernhard - like a bee just outside the frame of his Domenico Veneziano (or Baldovinetti) Medama. He looks so small, & tiny bee-thunders are about his brow & lips - the rich storminess of a summer buzzer.

We are getting happy in our Forest. And the Down & brakes behind Woodside where we go next Friday are filled with greater influence - some god has local habituation there, altho we do not know him yet.
The oaks now are rejuvenating - a colour of sun-burnt health pulses all over them - a wine of life is in their shoots.

The quoit-players haunt our grass-valley one hears the quoit ring as if of glass, while the dew rises - & the few rare, broad acclaims of success. One thinks of Discobolus & of Hyacinthus, & poetry rests, even as the moon, over the <our> grass-valley.
