p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 228; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 113v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: we have plucked in the bog asphodel spikes, Rufus’ hair.
I read to Francis
“O ancient Love” & c
But it seems to frighten people - they get under cover & hide from it. I supposed it is too widely universal, for most of the narrow lovers of Earth. They love “mortal, if thou are beloved”
They <Their> flesh touches its own warmth in that.

I must return to Paragon - rather to that visit to the Palace I left unchronicled. It was delicious. After dinner we were introduced to 3 new Italian Pictures - one, Early Tuscan, really noble & hieractic in effect - a calm Dream to live with.

My dress of black taffeta, with black & opal rushes, is welcomed by Shannon “What a beautiful dress you are wearing!” The pendants & jewels return on their makers eyes with fascination. Shannon takes us to the Shephard’s Bush station as guide to the reeling cabman, & Fay of course follows on foot as demi-gods out-pace mortals. We all wait the train under a night-sky of so velvet a texture it suggests fragrance

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 229; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 114r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: - one seems to smell the softness of the clouds.

Then on the Tuesday before we started for the Forest - July 12th - The Artists dined with us. Mary had got up a Bach afternoon, & Fay & Michael met there & from thence journeyed to Paragon together. Unfortunately the difficult great music had wrought Fay to nervous fatigue & headache. He looked white, as if dying in mind, at his arrival, though he was so excited he poured out a stream of talk on Bach. A prelude he heard was like the outpouring of a bag of jewels - dusk, with here & there one flash to measure the wealth of the cold gem-cascade. Bach composes on the brain itself, his music is organic only on that instrument - as some music is only organic on the heart, or the nerve-centres. He is the most taxing of all musicians - his high demand is almost of super-human quality. When we dine the heat & the festive dishes, meeting Bach in the [????] Painter’s body, produce a deadness of nausea - we quite fear the worst. But he revives.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 230; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 114v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Still the evening is spoiled by that exacting Bach, though Shannon is [????] merry & charming almost as in his youth. The talk after dinner is obliterated from my mind by anxiety & by the deadly heat.

Such terrible kettle-of-fish week before we attained the forest - contracts, the lease, the packing, the arrangements for 6 weeks’ absence, money arrangements, two dinners for our two rarest friends…we were more than half dead in the July hotness.

We read Hudson on the new Forest animals - of the voles, the handsome hornets, the lady-glow-worms who glow till they frightened the male, & then glow till they are last in the dimness of the wife. He tells of the dead snake-skin that for years casts its scales & becomes bright with spring. What similes!

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 231; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 115r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer
Tuesday, July 26
th

div.p: We drove in beaver-grayness through Boldrewood & over Stony Cross Plain. The small crab-apples I remember so well on the road between Stony Cross & Mark Ash at the point where the driver mentioned the name Bank & a horror fell on me - are still there, small & cloaked with pale red - tho’ I have not seen them for 20 years.

As we drive over the rough-coated plain a vast cloud of purple begins to grow - a low-down purple that has weeping as its promise. This sense of tears on a great landscape-verge is most moving. Michael is absorbed in the greatness of the influence & drives on, on-round by Stony Cross itself - a mist is on us; & over the new Inn, that desecrates the spot where <our> William Rufus was born, a sheet of fire. Then fire out of a sick vapour of tempest - such <a> rain as <that> runs down the Professor’s ears as if from gargoyles & makes his chest a bog. Our one thought is of hot water & hot brandy & a fire.
Wednesday And all day the after-rain of thunder drips und into soaked trees Michael & Francis have

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 232; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 115v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: a walk to Akers Down - of <to> the exquisite view in wh: Stony Cross is reborn. Meanwhile I place Henri & Dianne in our new Forest, & all the fresh sylvan discoveries we have made through round their love at Anet.

p.hi: Thursday

div.p: We have a glorious drive - mid-glory of the forest, before Francis leaves us: The Manor, Castle Malwood, Stony Cross (where we find with a jolly Mrs. Whitehorn a set of cottage-rooms engaged for August & garnished with a snarly dog-alas!) Rufus Stones (for Francis) Branley Woods & Broany enclosure - a world of driven cloud, of sun-covered wilderness, & trees in their own expanses of light - the firs blue, the hollies argent-dark, the beeches tawny, the oaks rubied with a new spring of leaflets. Such air P such laughter! The “peeps” at Castle Malwood have the gracious civility of Italian-Garden art.
All morning we have been arranging “The Tragedy of Pardon” – Tristam – to send to Milstead (of Duckworth & Co.) at Tommy’s suggestion.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 233; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 116r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: July 29th Woodside, Emery Down.

The Professor leaves a weeping forest unwilling to pack trimly for a 5 minutes transit, we let the live sponges leap about in the baruche. I have never felt so like sobbing over my boxes - full of the “broken meat” of our bottles & clothes. It is a day of awful jostle & damp, & towards evening, I fall ill.

Through an atmosphere still bleeding vapours I drag myself to the past; - then, perforce I must turn to the sun, & its cheery sign – the glade, the firm, fragrant high-road, the sandy bank, the hem uncertain line of railing, on wh: the mag-pie perched, to the forest. Black [surine?] from Bank [gr?] across the stream. All this fair lot was ours yesterday – I still see the glint of the Professor’s dress-shirt, as we paced the glade, - the gavel-bank, the birds, the little noises among the leaves, - all were ours. Henry likes the modern rooms with the round cherry-tree in front – I cannot - for me the deep humanity of an inn!
At Duckworth’s they are reading “O ancient Love of Chaos bred”

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 234; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 116v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: July 30th
a great letter from Painter –
Oh, enchanting!

In response to a letter from Michael, in which she said the real meaning of Christ’s saying “Depart from me, ye that work iniquity!” was “Depart all ye that are out of touch with me” - Painter comes into magnetic touch with the Poet.

“I have news. I have turned sculptor. I have modelled a man & a horse & now quite understand the rather youthful attitude of the Deity on the 7th day when he saw that it was good. Clay is a divine substance, responsive, attentive, definite yet liable to improvement also. I think man must have been modelled in some less admirable & ductile stuff. In a few days my two masterpieces will be cast in bronze & be ready for sonets sonnets & epigrams. One of the statuettes represents an actor with a mask; the second a Centaur with a sleeping baby-faun. Tomorrow I shall make a weeping terminal, & tomorrow more Centaurs and an Atys & a dawn of Venus, with her feet on the chest of a Triton, & a drinking Sphinx, & a poet bearing his chimera & a lot of “[Coshey?]” things.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 235; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 117r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: The carpets in the pink drawing-room look like a battlefield of dusty foot-prints (the feet of the sculptor are not beautiful) I have been working like a negro, unable, in fact, to stop away.
I hope you are well.
Yours, the Painter.
This letter blows from the Islands of Youth - a fresh Art! What is a fresh love to that?

When we came to our fr new quarters here yesterday in the torrent of rain I fell at the door-step & wrenched wrenched my garnet necklace - the rain continued black; Michael became ill & I numbed with anxiety & forlornness. But we woke to the dairy-fragrance of the air at dawn & to the great leaves & Kaleidoscopic spaces of pointed light, & to the the birds & motionlessness of a great cherry-tree. We had a saved feeling - and this morning we ate cake at the dear Inn, & traversed the lovely Boldrewood high-road again, our chief path with the Prof. - then rain - then this afternoon a drive over the Plain in thunder-showers, enjoying the crisp dripping crispness of

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 236; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 117v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: the fern. We almost slept in the softness with wet faces. After that we met a storm-veiled sun toward the West of Akers Down.
It is the hour when autumn oaks re-bud, their farthest branches red, as if a priest had struck them into sanctified blood to scatter all the forest.
Michael has been dreaming of sea-mice.
And Painter is a Sculptor, & divinely happy.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 237; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 118r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: I write to Painter
This is of the god! It is subtle, irresistible; it does not answer to the words that you are a sculptor – it is indeed news – tidings rather, & of the kind that makes a ruffle among the angels.

Henry & I go over the “to-morrow” list. Henry broods over the drinking Sphinx, but all my love - & all the foxity of my life to for “a weeping Terminal” In that – but I speak not: speech is not for that wh. can be wrought.
Could you, Painter, I wonder, be some year happy in the forest for a day or two? Could you be patient to learn to tongue of the moss, & all the accents of the trees? Henry knows not. I wonder.

I would far rather you were at the Palace with your clay. Painter, you have been called by one who is not your enemy, “an abstract eel”, & this too is for me your charm. Abstractness with attention is far better than “joy with economy.”

I cannot turn to the forest now that you have set me on the track of art, - & yet there is a cherry-tree the poets wake to at dawn – kaleidoscopic in its light through purified leaves, - where the buds, & they remember the cherry-harvest = & written in their old age of song; and there is the strange reddening & re-budding of the summer oaks, & shaking, & dropping, & sorrels.

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 238; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 118v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Henry is happy writing scenes in “Dian: Queen of Earth” – our title for the new play. Ah, Painter, Gaugin was her Sculptor _-who now? Just Diane sitting by the [????] of the River of Time – watching the rise & fall of it – no stag, & no crescent-moon – the symbolism in the figure!
You have behaved ill over Diane, not “fizzing” when I fizz, as Bernhard wd complain.
Farewell, with good fortune, as the Greeks say.
Michael

All the heavens are wide this third Forest Sunday - the cherry-tree is tongued & eloquent & little clouds are harboured in a bay of air, like a happy gala-fleet. The moss of the forest glows surprisingly; it has fattened with the rain - its [whorls?] & fronds are tender, almost sleek. The dead beech-leaves as we pass over them give us the experience of spiced & mummied rain - over them, & the sky & the lawns the sun is sprinkled in droplets of a golden shower.
We have an early greenwood walk. Then I begin the last scene in “Dian, Queen of Earth”, while Michael

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 239; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 119r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: writes to Fay & to Francis.

Then we walk in open noon, the wind over the sun, like a banner across a festival. And after lunch, still we walk, so warm & fresh are the hours. Our only trouble is a fear of the fierce dog next door - a poor animal tied up to become a fiend.
After tea we start of Renaissance – the beautiful terrace at the back of Akers Down.
The sun is hidden, & all the beech woods expend as dark clouds do - an awful deepening passes through them - they are stranger than the sun, as they sit in their grace while he passes.

Michael plunges in sylvan madness on – on & bears the ardour over her cheeks still. She says this day is the last of summer - it has attained, & autumn might begin tomorrow. She is very much [much] with the sky when we turn home.
August 1st – at last – & Bank Holiday

I drew in from the garden the 1st morning-glory. The red algi shoot up in the woods a sweet walk at sundown through the shining of the sweet gale past the dark water of alder drop – on lo the beechen <& hollied> spaces of “amiens’ song”
_ & an evening with Michael’s Wilverley Poems & As You Like It.

August 2
nd
Tuesday

div.p: We walk <wake> in awful depression - the purlieus of dying. The Forest seems to choke one in the night while one sleeps. We comfort ourselves with the thought Amy will soon be back at the Manor & a refuge will appear.
Then out into a lordly autumn day - to the dear Inn & the Highway from wh: one looks into Hyacinthian Discobolan glade. What sweep of light & branches, & dragon-fly.
The webs lie on the heath like fleeces of Fay-land, the beeches have a brown shade, that makes them look firmer to the eyes.
“La charmoire” of the Algi is very rich - the vermeil texture of their substance is worthy food for the fervent-tempered squirrels.

This afternoon we have driven in the by-ways at the heart of the Forest as never before. Not a high-road, except for a while our delicious Boldrewood Road. We tumbled over the beech-roots of Kit’s Hill, looked down in the beech & holly antiquity of Buckhill, paused at the Roman

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 241; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 120r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Arch & descended. Such a picture – that such should never be painted, because it is a picture, & man should never strive to do what nature has achieved. The water is green, a delight, in the hollow under the bridge. The roots are twisted perfectly, the shale-bank is perfect round about the runlets of the water.

And we hear from our Driver that the Romans built it to avoid the toll-gate on the other road – so his grandfather told him <many times>. They made a straight way to Cufnels…”so at least he told me” - adds the man, feeling the atmosphere dubious.
It is exquisite! The wooded Britons making their road-charges; & the imperial Road makers cutting straight a’head to avoid paying. I bore it - the laughter within grew an immortal joy.

Afterward we came to Holiday Hill, driving along three miles of Greenwood like that of Wilverley. Oh, the little oaks, crisped as with a tool, green & sunny - the wide green turf-way, & everywhere like an [????] [????] of waves, the brake-fern flaked with radiance! I could have gone on for an

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 242; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 120v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: Enchanted lifetime. Gods & Poetry live in these green enclosures - only societies of men & the forms of drama haunt the great unenclosed woods of beech & holly - Jaques & the Court of the Elder Duke Dianne de Poytiers or William Rufus.
That greenest green road, ever wh: our horse sprang on! That greenery in curl over it, & that rise of a subtle sea of form round every trunk!

Tea at Boldrewood Lodge, now demure under Lascelles’ despotism silence about us & tea discreetly brought out into the carriage. Before this Mark Ash with its memories of 20 years ago, of 2 years ago with the Professor. What small divine sorrel under the ancient Beech-ghosts! And I saw the fine Thorns, named after Michael, flourishing in a dim manner.

Tonight we have been up our James Hill in twilight. From a ledge we look down on the whole Boldrewood - the effect is of naked Forest caught unawares - its body seen - all those trees of <without> any

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 243; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 121r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: knowledge of their revelations. A night-bird weighed its own wing down, & in the distance the owls gave their cry, as if it came from that flesh & bone of forest, incarnate below us.
Wednesday _ Another lordly day _
“herrlich wie am voten Tag”
We sit on the Boldrewood High-Road & look down on our happy glen through the levels of gold beech-leaves.

In this harvest-heat we sit in our parlour, with the fire-slashed hawthorn of the shades suggesting coolness for on the mantle shelf, & pale & crimson mallows in the vases - rich & cool as old church-windows under the hottest sun.

At sundown we wander away to “Amiens’ Song” - from thence through the solitude at the heart of an old wood of beeches & hollies. Those beeches! Under them the Duke of As You Like It feasted, on them was Orlando’s sculpture. There is no question of their growing – only that they had have grown. The Past is their Overlord - ‘Antan’ - all that was before now. Yet our each sunset brightens their

p.hi: Notebook 18, Page Image 244; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 121v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer

div.p: small leaves to a delicacy of display, like an old man’s smile at a child going to bed.

They are very lovely & almost terrible in age & experience - Think of the millions of birds that have touched their leaves with a breeze - the myriads of insects that have afflicted or sung to their centuries!
Birds & insects of the 18th century - of Elizabeth’s days - of the time perhaps when chivalry was abroad & knights pricked at each other.

And the little Daedalus-paths through the hollies - we had to leave scraps of paper wherever we turned as faggot-gatherers advised us not to stray so deep. At last we sighted the High-Road, & turned back at the sound of military music from the army of volunteers, now at camp about the forest. Strange the sound of the drum accompanied by the call of peace from the Dove at the core of our Labyrinth. We were happy - freely happy to ourselves - Michael & Field.
